text: 2/17/2011 9:00:03 AM Bottle from Bierkoning. Hazy orange body with a big head. Nose of fruits, caramel and yeast. Taste is malty but really sweet and fruity. Not at all what I was expecting. Lots of caramel in a syrupy texture. Good.
Bottle at Craigs. Pours deep amber, nose and taste is sweet, malty, raisins.
Dark amber coloured and with an off-white head, medium duration. Sweet roasted aroma, hazel-nuts.

Color caoba oscuro, con reflejos rojizos y densa espuma color crema. Aromas dulces de toffee, caramelo, pasas y toque especiado. Cuerpo medio-bajo ,quizá demasiado ligero para el estilo, con inicio dulce y afrutado al que se añaden sabores acaramelados. Bastante bien.
Bottle. Cola pour with a big off white head that dissipated quickest. Chocolate, charcoal, raisin, hop. Medium body. Good carbonation. Perfect slightly acidic and sweet finish. Very nice
Bottle shared tonight by Dr Rob, thanks for the opportunity! Fruity caramel and brown sugar with a hint of chocolate offset with yeasty earthy flavors. This is a nice dubbel.

Botella de 65 cl en el lúpulo en septiembre de 2013. color oscuro casi negro con sabores y aromas maltosos, ligeramente dulces y algo tostados. Cuerpo medio. Tipo belga doble total. Normal, tal vez demasiado dulzona.
This one poured a lighter brown color with a beig head. Aroma was of caramel, dark fruits and belgian yeast. Falvor was the same, moderately spicey, toast, caramel and dark fruits. Ok.

This is a Belgian Style Abbey Ale or more accurately said, an attempt at one. The head was off white and rather small, and the look was a cloudy dark brown. The aroma was of sour hops. The taste was creamy (a tick on the Abbey Ale style inspection), with some caramel and a tiny amount of roasted coffee. It finished with a light sourness and there was pretty much no aftertaste. Not bad.

i cant remember the last time time i had a Capt Lawrence beer that wasnt over carbed, so this was a treat! .. . pours a deep molasses brown .. . mild headring, light lacing .. . bread, woody, plums, and cooked pear skin .. . light mouth .. . tasty beer, the abv is well masked as well .. . . Your heart stops when you sneeze. It doesnt. Thats called cardiac arrest.

Bottle. Moderate roasted grain, cereal, and chocolate milk for the malt, light to moderate cooked orange and perfume for the hops, moderate dough for the yeast, with brwon sugar, date, toffee, and a hint of vinegar. Head is small, creamy, light tan, with good slippery lacing and is mostly lasting, Color is muddy, medium brown. Flavor starts lightly sweet and lightly to moderately acidic, then finishes lightly sweet and acidic and faintly bitter. Palate is on the fuller side of medium, slick with a lively carbonation and a tart finish. A bit more tart than most Abbey Dubbels, but still a nice well rounded Belgian.

Bottle from Manchester W&L. Poured into a snifter. Rated from the middle of the bottle (2nd glass). A deep ruby color. Aroma of sweet plum, raisin and earth. Flavor is soft and earthy. Plum and roasty caramel notes. Lingering fruitiness.

Location/Date:Bottle shared with Dave on September 1st, 2013.
Appearance: Pours a dark opaque. 
Aroma: Aroma of dark fruit.
Taste: Heavy yeast, dark fruit
Palate:Medium body.
Summary: Enjoyable, Captain Lawrence always makes a good brew.

Bottle shared by portableparty! Hazy brown pour, nice head and lasting lasting with a light brown sugar and plum aroma. Flavor is more plum, a bit nutty with hints of clove. Not bad. Would certainly pick up if the price was right.

Bottle. Pours dark mohogany color with a tight fizzy khaki head that settles to a thin film. Aroma has a subtle fruitiness with raisins yeast slight funk and hidden toffee malt. Taste is a little bitter tart and nutty with roasted malt and funk. Palate is thin to medium with a slick dry finish.

bottle at BCTC.Dark burnt orange color. Nose is interesting, sweet and spicy with a touch of vanilla and figs. Taste biscuity, bread, yeasty and smooth. sweetness throughout with loads of dark fruits and tangerines.
22oz bottle pours brown with tan head. apple, fig, and malt aroma. sweet bready taste that finishes flat

Bottle. Pours dark brown with a quickly dissipating tan head. Nose is dark fruit and caramel. Taste adds some roastiness, chocolate malt and nuttiness. Palate is a little thin but smooth. This is very good but could use a little more body. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Yet another one where I cant compete with loineshawns rating. 750 ml beer from Secret Santa last time I did it. This was a geyser as soon as I cracked the cap just a little. Took 6 glasses to contain the foam. It sprayed all over the table, the floor, my clothes, my keys and phone on the table, and other peoples shit. Made a fool of me in front of 6 other people. The massive rocky beige head finally developed a hint of an amber beer underneath. It smelled fine; sweet malts, dry grains, dark fruits. A little metal in the flavor. Light-medium bodied, with low carbonation from what little beer was left. Dry mouthfeel. My keys still smell like beer. Fuck this asshole beer.

Bottle thanks to Shig. Clear dark amber/brown with an off white head. Aroma of toffee, bready malt, fruity esters and light spice. Flavor is bready malt, caramel with some fruity and spicy esters. Medium body with some alcohol heat. Really nice beer, very well balanced.

Bottle: Poured deep blackish brown with a thin tan colored head. Aroma was strong yeast, dark fruit, some bubblegum. Makes a very pleasant mix of dark fruits, sweet malts, nice alcohol warming on the palate. Im glad that this made a trip to Anchorage, very solid Dubbel!

Refrigerated 750 cl brown bottle poured into a trappist glass.  Pours translucent reddish brown with medium beige head.  Tight small bubble lacing, medium body, low carbonation, and nice caramel, ripe fruit, & dark candy sugar aroma.  Taste is dark ripe fruit (fig, raisin, and some dates), caramel, some nuts, and dark candy sugar.  Some complexity, enjoyably sweet, pretty easy to drink, I like this one.

Bottle at CGarvie tasting. Old-Skool label! It pours deep amber-brown with a thick yellow-white head. The nose is rather sweet...raisin, sultana, white grape and brown sugar. The taste is earth, light bitterness, spice, citrus, candied peel, raisin, dried fruit, brown bread and cherry. Medium body and fairly high carbonation. Not a whole depth of flavour. Ok.

From ZDKs tasting.  Vintage 2006.  The aroma is sherry-like, oxidized, very nice.  The appearance is clear amber/red, white head.  The flavor is like the aroma, sherry, bread, fruit.  The finish is sweet, sherry.  Excellent.
Bottle.  Thanks neal.   Unexpected plummy twang.  Slightly tart plum skin twang backed by a pleasant toasted nut.   Pretty good.
cheesy nose, fIzz hazy golden brown-some whispy  head I like it tardy good to ok  I like it good fine ok yeah
Bottle. Deep amber with off white head. Dusty dried fruit aroma. Taste of intense raisins, caramel. Quite fizzy with a clean finish.

bottle at home ... golden copper ... huge off white head ... soft sweet roast malts ... light bready nose ... soft fruits ... ligth fizz ... deep rich raisins ... mostly just rasins ... and not much else ... raisins raisins raisins and sultans.

750ml bottle, 2006 vintage, shared by Matt at Zach & Matts tasting. Pours brown with a small foamy tan head. Aroma is booze and dark fruits and spicy yeast. Taste is really beautiful, some sour notes along with some sweet notes, a great balance. Its like the beer has totally mellowed out with age. This was really enjoyable.
Fig nose, subtle. Clear brown, medium head. Mildy sweet, malt forward, low fruit flavor. Medium body, slight tang.

75 cl bottle.
Originally rated on 20110218.
Pours brown color with a large head. Aroma of caramel malts, toffee, spices and ripe fruits. Flavor of ripe fruits, caramel malts, yeast and chocolate notes.
This review is exported from olutopas.info with no comment. Original rating date  18.2.2011

Dark amber/cider color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of sweet malt, some yeast, & dark fruit; Flavor of sweet malt, yeast, caramel, dark fruit, and some spice; Nicely balanced; Surprisingly thin - but decent enough.
Draught at The Gingerman NYC sept 2012. Dark brown beer with an offwhite/beige head. Fruity and malty aroma. Fruity and roasted malt flavour with a sweet finish. Nice one :-)

At Han Dynasty with Ray and Jay (and many bottles over the years).  Pours a deep murky brown with tan head and lacing.  Aroma of dark fruits, cherry, caramel, raisin and some muted roasted malts.  Really great dubbel.  A mildly sour finish.
Botella. Color marron claro espuma beige y poco carbonico. Aromas a caramelo, maltas y frutas. En boca es dulce con alcohol bien integrado con buen final seco y dulce, quizas le falta cuerpo

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2013 1/4/13. 750mL bottle thanks to nulledge! Deep brown pour with a nice khaki head. Rich aroma of dark fruits, prunes, and burnt caramel. Nice flavor with the same characteristics but lots more lingering roast. A touch of alcohol.

Pours a dark brown with a thick off-white head. Aroma of roasty malt and caramel. Taste is dark fruit, chocolate and caramel with a finish of roast. Chewy and dessert like. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Hop-Head.dk. Clear dark reddish brown with a lasting beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, dried fruit and yeasty. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 151212

650ml bottle. This one pours a murky brownish red with a fairly authentic Belgian-looking head. Nice malty aroma with notes of red wine and candi sugar thrown in. I picked out apples, berries, orange peel, raisins and a hint of vanilla in the taste. Normally Id be delighted with a mixture like that, but this dubbel just didnt hang together well enough on the tongue. Its not as drinkable as the best of this style and its individual elements didnt converge well enough. A good effort but not in the top tier.

from Erzbierschof - slightly hazy dark brown beer with a long lasting beige foam left; earthy malty aroma with notes of ripe fruits; a decent malt backbone, some sweetness and a late earthy bitterness; slightly nutty and quite dry malty finish; notes of pear - true to style

This pours a dark brown color with a frothy tan head that leaves some scattered lacing.  Picking up figs, raisins, brown sugar, and Belgian yeast in the aroma.  The flavor shows raisin bread, dates, lightly toasted nuts, and candi sugar.  This isnt too sweet as I thought it migt be, but the flavors are kind of ho hum.  The body is a shade light.  Not to say this is a bad beer, because its plenty enjoyable, its just not great.

Bottled. Pours slightly hazy and brown with a medium sized off-white head with fair lacing. Nose of malt, nuts and ripe fruit. Sweet flavor again with nuts and ripe fruit along with prunes, figs, spicy notes and it ends up more dry with alcohol notes. The body is medium, texture oily and CO2 soft to average. A nice bid for a dubbel.
22oz bottle. The smell is wine like, fruits, caramel, buttered rum, raisan, and punch. The look is brown to red, clear, and has a light tan head. The taste is fruity, malts, raisans, yeasty, and ok.
Brown with Mohagany accents and a large beige head. Aroma is of bread dough, raisins, brown sugar, chocolate. Taste is of figs, dates, raisin, caramel, brown sugar.

Bottle from the brewery. Very fresh.  Its not what I would expect from a dubbel.  Its a little sharper and almost stout like.  It dark brown letting only a little light through.  Big frothy head dissipates quickly with no lasting lace.  The aroma is earthy but mostly fresh toasted rye bread.  The flavor is a slightly lactic and with a lot of almost smoky grain and pepper.  I get a little ginger and fruit but not much of the dark fruit, sweet bready malt and yeast character of a typical dubbel. Soft palet but finishes a bit peppery and warm, though the alcohol is hidden (not that big anyway).  Its good and unique but Im surprised they are calling it a dubbel.  Still very drinkable.
Bottle. Dark brown with big beige head. Aroma is malt, yeast and dark fruits. Flavour is malt, yeast, medium sweet, dark fruits, plume, hop, little bitter, raisin and notes of berries.

0.75l bottle from CrackedKettle. Been savoring this for a while now. It immediately after popping the cap fills the air with a sweet light dubbel-yeasty aroma. It pours a heavy cloudy dark amber-brown body with a really good looking big dense and heavy lacing light beige head. As mentioned the aroma is really present in this one - even if its almost as good as fridge-cold. Fruity and sweet with a clear acidic twitch, sticky raisins, really malty and quite delicious. In the taste I get first a sweet malty base with chocolate hints and some acidic touches, then it gets a bit more yeasty before it continues with lots of sour green gooseberries, oxidization , banana sweetness, a soft gentle hint of red wine vinegar and a little bit of mossy wood and alcohol. Not to sour overwhelming or anything, but there is a soft sour cream-like flavor in the finish that Im not sure it should have been here. Still, I fancy both that and the beer itself. Cheers Jeff! 11.09.2012
Aroma is mildly boozy with raisin, fig, and caramel apple. Flavor is earthy/bready with a mild bitterness...not as fruity as some dubbels. Mouthfeel is full and silky with a roasty/bitter dry finish

Sample at 20th Vermont Brewers Festival. Another enjoyable beer at the festival - pours Hazy dark brown with a biege head. Doughy malts, figs, yeast, some caramel. Moderate to high carbonation, moderate body, bit sweet with an underlying bitterness, becomes a bit dry, nice complexity on the finish.
Draught at the Ginger Man, Manhattan. Dark brown color, tan-brown spongy small head, caramel-chocolate aroma, hoppy sour taste, medium carbonation, long finish. Nice beer.

Draught at Ginger Man, NYC. Dark amber beer with a nice rich beige head. Yeasty malty aroma, coriander, banana, citrus, grapes, hop notes, caramel, some dark bread. Chocolate flavor, vinous, sourish notes, cocoa, yeast, coriander, grapes, banana notes, some hops, pepper, citrus, licorice notes. Well balanced with a fruity peppery finish. Alcohol is well hidden.
Bottle. Deep brown color...lacing lasts on top of beer, not glass. Taste is malty, nutty and sweet with a mild boozy aftertaste. Better and more flavorful as it warms u

Pours dark brown with tan head. Sweet dark fruits, candy, brown sugar, purple grape juice. Syrupy texture. A little too sweet for my liking, but if you like sweet, you might like this one. It is not boring or bad, just too sweet for me.

Pours an opaque brown with a medium tan head...great retention and lacing.  Aroma is mildly boozy with raisin, fig, and caramel apple.  Flavor is earthy/bready with a mild bitterness...not as fruity as some dubbels.  Mouthfeel is full and silky with a roasty/bitter dry finish.

750ml bottle into a chalice. New style logo bottle cap. Poured at cellar temperature.

A - Very dark/brown body. Somewhat clear when held up to the light. One finger dirty light tan head that sticks around forever. Excellent lacing and retention.

S - Not too far off from genuine Belgian dubbels or strong ales. Chewy figs, cherries, ripe bananas, caramel, toffee, brown sugar, and bready yeast. Like other reviewers I am getting some faint earthy mint.

T - Starts off with bready malts, caramelized figs, bananas, and cherries. Layers of mint, earthy grass, tobacco and spicy yeast. Kind of watery and muddled with an acetic soured malt aftertaste. Mouth feel is light to medium, with silky carbonation and a noticeable alcohol presence.

O - Kind of a let down. Appearance wise it looks excellent, and the aroma was rather impressive for an American brewed dubbel...but the flavors and mouth feel just fell flat. Watery, thin, unbalanced flavors, and a harsh aftertaste.

Lightly hazed pour with frothy tan head and lace. Aroma of sour malt and light brown sugar. Sweet malt with as sour kick and a nice earty bitter. Medium bodied with aggressive carbonation. This bottle had been in the frige for 2 years. The sour just wasnt right. Didnt make the beer terrible but just off. tried a bottle with JC Wattsrugger a couple to days later less sour and mor sweet. Initial rat 3.4 adjusted after 2nd bottle to reflect this beer

Opaque brown pour,  Malty aroma with a little cola, barbeque sauce, and pleasant floral notes.  The taste is equally impressive and complex.  Sweet, bready malt, followed by drying hops and a little sea salt.  There are none of the off-notes Ive come across in some dubbels.  Balanced and delicious - this is now my top-rated dubbel.

Bottle, 22oz, at RBNAG-11. It pours an unclear, light amber color and a small, off-white head. Lightly sourish nose, with a refreshing scent of berries. Some maltyness in the back. Berries, dried fruits and maltyness in the flavor, lacking on complexity. Full-bodied, pleasant carbonation. A decent one, but rather boring, I see no reason to buy this instead of a top notch Belgian dubbel. 111015

On tap at the brewery.  Deep brown with reddish-purple hues, large long-lasting tan head, active carbonation, and notable lacing.  Aroma is big plum and raisins with hints of dark chocolate and roasted malts.  Taste is similar with dark fruits evident upfront followed by pumpernickel bread and spicy yeast.  Big mouthfeel with flavors lingering on the palate.
Hey beer are you sick!?  Weird infected double kinda sucks.  Light sour and medicinal brettyness dont copliment a sweet malty double at all.  Really dumb.
Ah bretted. Cant really enjoy my favorite style and this is fucking gay. Thats Scott. Cheers.

75 cl bottle @ OHaras Freehouse. Rated on 18.02.2011
Aroma is sweetish with caramel, chocolate and brown sugar. Flavour has some dark fruits, caramel, toffee and some brown sugar. Too sweet and not good.

Originally reviewed: 1/18/10. Poured into a tulip glass. Pours a cloudy dark amber/orange with a big rocky off-white head on top. Great retention; left little lace. Scents of apples, yeast, and light alcohol. 

Full body on this and carries a high amount of carbonation on the tongue as most Belgian styles do. Flavors of roasted apples, other dark fruits, and rounded out with a slight yeasty twang on the finish. This was a pretty good Dubbel. Not my favorite style, but this was a treat.

The pour is amber in color with a huge off-white head.  The aroma is overwhelmingly heavy on the grape.  Very vinous and fruit with some sweet toffee and bready malt.  The flavor is perhaps even moreso than the aroma.  This also has a touch of lactic tartness (which I think is probably unintentional).  Not really all that dubbel-like.
Hazy amber with a white head - malts in the aroma along with some fruits - malt taste with some caramle in it - ok
Bottle at RBNAG-11. Red amber colour with a beige head. aroma is sourness, fruit, caramel, spices, malt. Flavour is sourness, fruit, caramel, spices, sugar, yeast.  Medium body. Nice beer.

Courtesy of Joe I take it. It pours amber with tan head. The big aroma offers up some roasted malts mixed with oak notes, red wine and a light lemon like acidity. The taste has tartness right off the start that leans quickly toward red wine. By midway I get a bit of roasted malts and spicy yeastiness coming to the surface. It seems to add a touch of vanilla sweetness into the finish.

750 ml bottle poured a clear reddiush brown with a lasting tan head. Aromas of carmel, toffee, fruittiness, brown sugar and light yeast. Palate was light bodied and crisp. Flavors of brown sugar, carmel, toffee, light fruittiness and light yeast with a crisp lingering brown sugar finish.

on tap at the Dutch into a chalice. amber hue short off white head with average retention, light lacing cap. scent is clean if not boring. taste is slight clove, dark fruits, hint of booze. medium bodied and warming. not a bad dubbel, would not consider this a benchmark by any means.

750 ml bottle @ RBNAG-11. Hazy orange body with a big tan head. Aroma is fruity, spicy and mild malty. Flavor is really fruity, a bit like peaches, spicy, yeast, light caramel and some mild acidity. Medium body. Feels to light and quaffable for a Belgium dubbel, but decent and nice anyway.

Bottled @ Beer Temple (from notes): Red color, muddy. Off white head. Aromas: red fruit, malty sweet, caramel. Flavor is medium sweet and medium sour. Finishes lightly bitter. Not sure if the sourness was intentional, but it doesnt fit the beer.

Bottle received in a trade (no name on bottle?).   Pours a slightly hazy dark brown color with a medium, dense beige head.  The aroma has a moderately malty aroma of brown sugar and caramel, with some ripe fruits like figs or dates.  The flavor has quite a bit of sweet maltiness upfront with caramel and brown sugar.  Additional notes of doughy bread, figs and dates.  The finish has some hints of alcohol.  Medium bodied.

Bottle from Secret Santa, Thanks! Pours Opaque brown, large dense light brown head, Fruity aroma. On the sweeter side for the style, plum, malt, sugar dominate, there is a sourness on the tongue, aftertaste. A good brew, just was expecting abit more dryness.

Shared bottle @RBNAG-11. Tall foamy blond head. Unclear brownish-red body. Bubble-gum fruitiness hit the nose first, then fine scent of caramel. Dark bready malt flavor. Some acid, some fresh fruitiness. Crisp in the mouth. Light acidic fruit ending. Yum!

Bottle: &nbsp Muddy brown, large frothy off-white head, copious amounts of lacing. &nbsp Strong bready nose, lots of 
dark pitted fruit, this one seems the biz. &nbsp Sweet bready dark pitted fruit on the tongue. &nbsp Must say this is a good 
example for an American made brew. &nbsp Has a bit of a sour prune aspect to it, but its light and compliments the otherwise 
sweet maltiness. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate to full, tiz a bit spritzy on the tongue which is what I pretty much 
came to expect from Captain Lawrence. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel arent heavy, but instead a little bubbley and moderate. &nbsp 
Finishes with a good balance of malty breadiness, sweetness, and a hint of dark pitted fruit sourness. &nbsp More Belgian 
like than most American examples. &nbsp Worthy.
15.10.2011. 0,75l Bottle. Dark brown colour with off- white head. malty with sour aroma. Aromas of berries.

Bottle 750ml @ RBNAG-11
Pours cloudy amber with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, dried fruits and some sourness. Taste is medium sweet, light bitter and light sour. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.
Bottle shared at RBNAG. Glowing dark amber. Sweet malt, short body, citrus finish.

75cl bottle. Hazy amber orange colour with a medium big head. Aroma is sweet and laden with toffee, caramel and sweet malts. Flavour is bittersweet. Notes of peach, toffee, grape and belgian yeast. Some brown sugar. A bit too fruity for a belgian dubbel.
Bottle. Pours amber with an off-white head. Aroma of hay, malt, grains, fruitiness and yeast. Flavor is sweet caramel with some aourness and yeast. Medium body, average carbonation.

750 ml bottle into tulip, no bottle date.  Pours nice hazy reddish orange color with a fairly dense 2 finger khaki head with amazing retention that reduces to a thick lacing cap.  Some bits of lacing cling to the glass as well.  Tons of carbonation streaming up from the bottom of the glass.  Aromas of huge grape juice, raisin, molasses, caramel, chocolate, nuttiness, and spices.  Huge aromas here I could smell as soon as I poured it.  Nice stuff.  Taste of big white grape, caramel, toasted malt, pepper, spices, bread, and molasses up front; with some chocolate and nutty notes near the finish.  A slight bit of tartness in the back adds a different aspect to this, with lingering notes of chocolate, nuttiness, spices, molasses, and caramel.  Finish is excellent, not too dry, leaving a nice amount of linger flavors.  Nice balance of flavors as well.  Alcohol is nicely hidden with none noticed except for a small warming on the finish.  Great drinkability.  Medium carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a nice and creamy mouthfeel.  Overall this is definitely an outstanding dubbel with tons of flavor and great balance.  This improved a lot as it warmed up.

750 ml bottle. This one poured a cloudy, caramel brown color with a red hue and topped by a huge head of tan colored foam that slowly recedes to a thin film leaving jagged lines of lace around the glass. The aroma is malt forward with sweet chocolate, toasted caramel, toffee, and nougat all layered together. There is also some light raisins and figs in there to give a nice fruit character to things. The flavor follows suit with the toasted caramel and sweet nougat malts blending nicely with the raisins, figs, and plums. There is not much hops to speak of, but the belgian yeast keeps things from getting overly sweet. Nearly full bodied with subtle carbonation that leads to a sweet caramel covered raisin finish. This is a really tasty dubbel. Good stuff.
Draft at rattle with Andrew, streets, Brendan and baron. Pours a hazy reddish brown. Aroma is sweet malts. Mouthfeel is thin with notes of sweet malts and fruit. Somewhat roasty and chalky.

Tap at Pony Bar. Pours a dark burgundy with moderate khaki head. Aroma of red table wine, black pepper, and hops with some chocolate in the background. Flavor is similar but with more sticky caramel flavor. Overall it is representative and something I would gladly take but not actively seek out.

Red pour, big foamy off-white head. Aroma is not large.
Flavor is dried fruit, caramel malt, spice, yeast. Slightly sour.
Pours amber with off white head.  Aroma is peaches and plums...it smells sweet.  Taste is sweet with a tart almost acidic finish.  Very interesting.  Thick and creamy mouthfeel.

Bottle pours orange/brown with a khaki head. Aroma shows notes of fig, date, plum, caramel, and brown sugar. Flavor shows the same with additional notes of milk chocolate, light roast, and a touch of earthy hops.
Draught from the man of ginger on 36th.  Pours dark, smallish whitehead, aroma is dark fruits, brown sugar etc, some malts.  A nice dubbel.
Pours a brown color with a off white head. Has a yeasty smell to it. Has a begian yeast taste with some dark fruit in back. Its a bit thin for a double but not to bad Ive had worse.

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2011 Draft @ Coalhouse Pizza in Stamford, CT. Served in a mason jar, this beer arrived in a bubbly darkish brown body with velvet and violet tints. Overall, this is a very malty beer that has notes of cola, lavender, sea salt, soap and brown sugar. To be honest, the aftertaste of this beer reminded me of cola and vodka. Maybe its my strange palate, but this is so far my least favorite beer from Captain Lawrence, a truly first-rate brewery.

(750ml bottle). Pours apricot with off-white head.  Aroma is tomato, caramel and florals.  Taste is malty sweet with some light hops.  Medium bodied with oily texture and slightly bitter finish.  Decent beer, but not a great dubbel.

Deep amber pour light beige head light lacing .... sweet malty and dark fruity aroma ... taste is of dark fruity yeast and caramel malts, little bitter hop and roasted malt with a malty and light bitter hop finish ... an easy drinking dubbel not as smooth and rich as advertised or rated at least the abv is hidden well

750ml bottle in a Trappist glass.  Pours opaque brown with a thick, lacy, beige head.  Aroma of Belgian spicy yeast, caramel malts, dark fruit, and light floral hops.  Flavor about the same with a strong malt presence and underlying spice and fruits.  Average texture.  A pretty good dubbel.  I used to hate on dubbels, but beers like this are an example of why Im starting to like them

Reviewed from notes. Thanks to BeerWorld for this bottle.

Poured into a tulip. Appearance is amber-brown with a light head and some mild lacing with staying power. Nose is dark fruits, toast, and a bit of spicing. The flavor is malty with some dark drugs and yeast. Good body with nice carbonation and a touch of heat. Drinkability is good, though I could have used a bit more complexity.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-04-2010

Bottle, bought @ Ølbutikken, Cph.
Light hazy deep red with a big, staying, frothy, off-white head. Aroma is sweet, quite a lots of raisins and plums, some chocolate, light cellar, a bit of oranges. Some mild spices as well. Highish prickly carbonation, rather light mouthfeel. Flaovur is mild, some slight metallic notes (probably from the carbonation), chocolate, mild roasted and some fine dried fruit characters. Fairly vinious with a slight touch of tannins. A bit of a mess, really, still drinkable and fine, but not really what constitutes a great dubbel.
Bottle from Ølbutikken. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are raisin, plums, yeast, caramel and hops.
0.75l - Red/purple pour, lihgt carbonation.  Nose was yeast.  Palate was a sour, sweet stone fruit or maybe like a fig newton.  I liked this.

Tasted on 3/13/11 from a 750mL crown-capped bottle, which I assume was bottled at some point in 2010.  Pours cloudy amber with a huge beige head that slowly settles into even lace, and coats the inside of the glass with lace as well.  The nose is somewhat hard to smell due to carbonation, but there are underlying aromas of caramel, brown sugar, chocolate, stewed fig, walnut, date and just a hint of fruity yeast.  The flavor is very malty and sweet up front with caramel and brown sugar, moving to more of the date and fig, and the walnut coming through nicely, and a bit of bitterness coming through on the back.  The body is medium with lively carbonation and a long caramel, chocolate, date, and fig finish.

Bottled at Pikkulintu, Helsinki. Reddish brown color. Raisiny, toffeish and tart aroma. The flavor is also toffeish and raisiny with clovey spiciness. The flavor is also very tart and fruity which I found conflicting with dark malt character. Highly carbonated.

Bottle (75 cl) from the Cracked Kettle. Clear mahogny, medium tan head. Fruity aroma with red berries, some toffee, and some vanilla. Meidum bodied, medium carbonation. Dry with a bit of wine barrel acidity.

Poured into a snifter.

4.0 A: Lightly hazed dark amber color. Little yeasties or something uniformly throughout. Three fingers of off-white frothy head with good retention and plenty of lacing.

2.5 S: Smells like a saison as opposed to a dubbel. Barnyard funk and peppery yeastiness are by far the strongest aromas. Light apple fruitiness. I dont know how this is as dark as it is without smelling like anything associated with beers this color. Pretty boring.

3.0 T: At least this tastes like a dubbel. Unfortunately it isnt a very good one. Toffee, light raisin and plum fruitiness, some tobacco. A bit more bitter than Id like. Again, theres some funkiness in the form of muskiness. It doesnt really work in this beer though because there isnt enough spiciness or dark fruitiness in the forefront. Some peppery yeast.

3.5 M: Light to lighter medium body. A bit too much carbonation, which is pretty active and spritzy. Could be a bit smoother due to the carbonation.

3.0 D: Ive certainly had better dubbels than this. Now at least I know better about this one. Theres really nothing good about it.

Edit: It tastes a hell of a lot better with the yeast mixed in, but the bottle didnt state to do that, so the scores stand.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-06-2010 00:34:25
Active carb, very strong head.  Leather and rose petal, dense and filling.  Foggy full mouthfeel, raspberry and cinnamon.

Bottle from 2006 at the 2010 Funky 6. Pours a somewhat murky, orange-brown with a strong, off-white head. Aroma holds overripe fruits, burnt toffee and Belgian yeast. Lots of dark, berry fruits in the flavor with sweet malts and caramel. Medium to full in body with soft to average carbonation. Sweet on the finish, a touch syrupy, with more caramel, cane sugar, dried fruits and toasted bread. Very nice beer.

Bottle shared by Adam, thanks! Poured a hazy deep caramel brown with a white head that lasted throughout the beer. Aroma had notes of sweet grains, cookie and caramel with a slight metallic note. Flavor had sweet grains, caramel and a bit of backing sweet fruit.

(Bottle) Pours dark amber with brown notes. Nougat coloured head. The aroma is of flowers, coriander, milk chocolate, bread and herbal hops. Some off-aromas of sour bacteria notable. The flavour is light sweet, light bitter and light to medium acidic. Chocolate, spices, yeast and bready malt. The mouthfeel is tart and off tasting with medium carbonation. Citric finish with alight milkiness. Medium bodied.

Bottle. 25.4 oz. Split with Dev on Christmas Eve. Pours a shiny, yet hazy chestnut with a tall, creamy, tan head which rests atop the beer like a sponge. Aroma of doughy yeast, cherry, slight Brett notes, and oaky hints. Medium bodied with a rich, supple, velvety smooth palate. Slight sourness in the finish. This is an excellent dubbel, and but for the 8%, would make a quite enjoyable sessioner. (Though the alcohol is not at all present in the taste.)

Shared bottle courtesy of gunnar. Finger thick tanned head on a murky deep golden body. Camfer wood, spicy Belgian yeast present in the aroma. Acidic it grows in the mouth. Off or intentional? Full body.
texture is nice and flavors are mellow. nicely balanced malts with very strong fruit (apple, cherry) and a nice touch of sour.  i can see why the captain is known for the sours.

Bottle from Cracked Kettle, Amsterdam. Pours deep amber with a spongy off-white head. Aroma of fruits and sugar. Taste is sweet malty, caramel, wood even some smoke here, that makes this almost astringent for me.

Bottle, kindly shared by gunnar. Brown colour, big off-white head. Aroma of Belgian ale yeast, brown sugar and spices, hints of camphorwood. The flavour has more fruity acidity than I expect from a dubbel, some spicy and woody notes too.

Bottle. Pours a clear amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty spicy yeasty aroma. Fruity malty spicy yeasty flavor. Has a fruity malty spicy finish with some yeasty hints and dark fruit hints in the aftertaste.

Bottle from yobdoog. Thanks!Pours a deep, rich mahogany/amber with an aroma of thin sour citrus bread and sweet plumb.  Notes of melon and vine also are noted.  Flavor is melon-heavy bread and rotten earth.  Average mouthfeel.  Probably a bit oxidized.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Pours dark hazy reddish brown with off white head, very carbonated and fizzy.  Aroma is alcohol, nuts, caramel, and some bread.  Taste up front is some caramel, biscuit, touch of bready earth, some yeast character, and some roast at the end with a touch of alcohol.  Pretty good stuff.

750 ml bottle @ Olutravintola Pannuhuone. Rated @ 30.6.2010.
Pours a hazy orange colour with a medium white head. Very dubbel-like aroma which includes sweet malts, fruits and caramel. Same elements on the flavour too. Alcohol comes a bit too much through. Medium bodied, oily texture and soft carbonation. Abbey Dubbel above average but nothing special.

Deep amber colour, not much hea. Aroma is caramel malts, some slight syrup and mild dark dry fruits. Flavour is earth, mild alcohol, some caramel and syrup. Mild yeast as well.
Pours muddy brown with tannish brown head. Nose is dark fruits, sweet malts, brown sugar and Belgian yeast. Taste follows suit with a nice, subtle complexity of hazlenuts and maple.

Capped 750 from Oak Tree. Pours hazy ruddy amber with a three finger foamy off-white head. Aroma is quite malty with some herbal aspects. Medium plus body with foamy carbonation. Flavor is sort of minty malt with some citrus and yeast/spice. Really grabs the mouth. Finishes a bit malty, but with some earthiness. Very interesting, very unusual, and very tasty.

Medium copper pour with a rather rapidly dissipating head.  Aroma is dark, almost burnt caramel with hints of green apple skin.  The flavor is a bit bizarre, it reminds me of powdered Quik or chocolate protein shake mix only with a bit more caramel flavor.  Not really bad, but I am not a fan.

From a 750 into a snifter.  This bottle is about a year plus old.  Pours with a gusher of white frothy head. Waaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaayyyyy too much!!!! Mouthfeel is fizzy, medium with a little tingle from the alcohol.  Taste is of alcohol, first and formost, but its not overpowering.  Dark fruits prevail for the mostpart. Big swing and a miss from CL.  This is my second time trying a beer from this NY brewery and will most likely be my last.  Maybe this bottle was infected because it tasted like sour apples plucked out of a  cats litter box.  Unfortunately, I brought this dud to the tasting.  At the end of the night every bottle was empty, except for old captain lawrence which was shamefully still half full.  Embarrassing.............

75cl traded bottle with the blue car label thats been hiding out in the cellar for about 2 years.  Pours a ruddy brown color with a medium tan head that dissolves into a film. Just hints of lacing. Pretty big aroma of dark fruit, molasses, sweet malt and yeast.  Nice flavor that really focuses on the fruit and malt with just a touch of bitterness in the finish. Pretty true to the dubbel form. Well done.

cloudy brown, smooth large offwhite head.
very nice aroma, yeasty, belgian, fruity.
flavor is delicately yellow fruity, caramel, nice fruirty citrussy note to it all, i really like this mild, full fruity flavor.

Bottle. Cloudy amber with a thick off white head. The aroma is loads of caramel, spices, clove, sweets and molasses. Spicy flavour with loads of caramel and some tobacco. Lots of berries in the finish. Slight sour touch in the finish. Actually very good.

(Bottle, 0.75 l, at Pikkulintu) Poured ambed and lighly hazy. Head was medium sized, bit bubbly and white. Aroma contained malts, green apple and fruitiness. Palate was medium bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were malts, sourness, fruitiness, mildly chocolate and bitterness. Aftertaste was sour and malty.

750 ml bottle. Finland.
Hazy brown colour with small off-white head.
Toffee, malt and mild alcohol in aroma.
Flavour is malty with Belgian yeast and alcohol. 
Another American interpretation of fine Belgian beer style gone... bad?

Bottle. Pours a clear, dark copper beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is malt, caramel, alcohol and spices. The flavor is close to the nose with some additional pepper. The palate has a high carbonation level and some alcoholwarmth. Overall a good beer, but not impressive.

Bottle 750ml. @ home.Clear medium to dark orange amber color with a large, frothy to creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, off-white to beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, caramel, nutty, moderate hoppy, citrus - orange, moderate to heavy yeasty, fruity, spices, sweet and acidic tobacco. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet, light acidic and moderate bitter with a average to long duration, dry, wood, sharp. Body is medium, texture is oily and sticky, carbonation is soft, finish feel is light alcoholic. [20100622]

(Old BA rate - bottle)
Poured with a nice 3/4 finger of lightly tan creamy head that held quite well; very hazy light brown color that hints at orangish. Fresh dark grapes; hint of sweet malts; peppery and vinous aromas. Vinous and dry; dark grape sweetness; a bit bready; nice enough, but not great. Thinner to medium MF; very lively, prickly carbonation. Nicely drinkable, and its definitely within my expectations for the style. Its a nice change from some of the sweeter versions that tend to come up more often.
