Hazy deep orange color, big cloudy off-white head. Grassy, grainy-yeasty aroma. Caramel, yeast, alcohol and tartness in the flavor. Not a dubbel-like at all. Sour berryness dominates.

Pours deep copper into a trappist glass. Off-white micro head with excellent retention recedes leaving sheet lacing to skim surface. Dark pit fruit aromas. Thick and sweet with upfront dates and plums turning to slightly sour fig in the lasting finish.

750 ml bottle; thanks to maxxdaddy for the trade; pours cloudy dark orange with thin white head; sweet aromas of dry yeast, candy malts and peaches; fruity and a little dank with raw, frosty oranges, peaches and lemons; not what youd usually expect for a dubbel, but pretty tasty nevertheless

Bottle. Pours a hazy reddish amber/brown with a thin off-white head. Sweet and malty aroma with caramel, dried fruit and a hint of toffee. Flavor was slightly sweet with caramel malts, dried fruit, brown sugar and a touch of alcohol.   decent brew

Pours a dark chestnut amber color with a thick foamy yellowish tan head with decent retention, only slowly fading into a lasting ring. Minimal spots of lacing left behind.

Roasted malty aroma which is kind of one dimensional for the style with hints of dark fruit, spice and alcohol.

Full bodied with a lot of dark roasted maltiness balanced by some plum/raisin dark fruit notes, chocolate, spicy and alcohol heat. Nice balance of sweetness from the dark fruit and dry finish. Pretty drinkable.

2007 edition poured into my Bornem Goblet

A-Body is a very hazy translucent medium brown hue. Pours with a nice 1-2 finger creamy off-white head. This eventually fades to the typical eggshell covering seen in a lot of abbey beers and has perfect retention from there. Small traces of lacing left in the glass. When held up to the light the cloudiness is very thick and somewhat dynamic.

S-The nose is big and malty. Almost reminds me of a Scottish ale. Lots of chocolate going on in the nose but also a hint of tart raisins and spicy Belgian yeast.

T-Upfront the dry semi-tart raisin flavor dominates but has a substantial cocoa backbone and a hint of yeast. A splash of phenols and a bit more raisin tartness come out for the finish as well as a hint of spicy Belgian yeast. Left to linger is a hint of raisin and a warm alcohol blanket.

M-Wonderful. Low to medium carbonation and a smooth and creamy feel that has a balance of malt and yeast.

D-I love Belgians, but the Dubbel is one style from the Belgian line up that I have not found and example that I could drink over and over again. This is that example. This is an excellent Dubbel (though the ABV is a bit higher than expected) and is everything that I find "good" in that brew. Very well done by Captain Lawrence and I am looking forward to trying more brews from this great brewing Co.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-21-2008 04:19:52
Hazy amber with a small off-white head. Aroma of fruits and raisins, with a hint of diacetyl. Dry caramel malty flavour with fruity notes. Pretty plain compared to Belgian dubbels
Pours dark amber with a beige head. Aroma is malt, fruity, clove, grassy hop and alcohol. Flavour is malt, fruity, clove and pepper.
Bottle @ Odense Tasting, April 2010. Pours cloudy amber with a large fluffy head on top. Nose and taste is sweet malty and yeasty. Some spices and vaguely citric. Medium bodied.

Bottled. Amber coloured. Unclear. Dense light brown lasting head. Aroma of sterin, grape, spice, fruits and light caramel. Flavour of sterin, citrus, fruits, berries, spice, yeast and some vague liqourice. Medium bodied. Has a grapy end with loads of berries. Quite refreshing but a bit bland and subdued.
Off-white creamy head and a hazy red-brown body. Aroma of yoghurt, caramel, raw malt, red wine. Oily texture. The taste is light sour, medium bitter and light sweet. The beer seem to be "unfinished"

Bottle. High creamy and long lasting off-white head. Hazy orange body. Apple pear grapefruit lemon grassy hoppy aroma with hints of the alcohol.Nicely hopped barley malt flavor with fruity notes. High carbonation, long bitter aftertaste.

Bottle - thanks oteyj.  Chestnut brown pour with a thin beige head.  Nose is sweet, mainly candied sugar and toffee.  Lightly fruity and what seems to be chocolate malt.  Tastes more of caramel and chocolate malts with light bits of carmelized sugar.  Toffee, dark fruits, and light vinous notes.  Really, as this warms up more, it becomes quite good.
Bottle at Morten & Heidis - shared !!! Clear brown - offwhite head. Sweetness, spicy, yeasty, nutty, roasted, soapy, orange, fruity, licorice yeasty, dried fruits, prunes, raisins, ligh bitterness.

Bottle at QUAFF meeting. Cloudy dark orange with sustaining off-white head. Nose is malty rich sweetness, dark fruit, and caramel. Flavor is a mix of dark fruit esters and rich bready malts, hints of roast and caramel, Belgian yeast character, low bitterness, finishes sweet. Full body, modest carbonation, thick texture. A full flavor example of the Dubbel style, deep complexity and malty-ester profile.

Bottle via trade thanks to koopa on BA.  Pours slightly hazy reddish-amber with an off-white head that leaves foam on the beer.  Smell is a little metallic, but good otherwise.  Belgian yeast and candi sugar, along with cherry/red berry.  Flavor is actually not metallic at all.  Caramel malt, Belgian yeast, red berries, and candi sugar.  Medium body with some metallicity on the mouthfeel.

Pours a nice head with a ruby/brown body. The sweetness and malt come together nicely. There is a slight wine like quality to it. Some fruit. Plumb. Little cherry. Not heavy for a Dubbel, but very enjoyable.

Bottle purchased at the brewery.  Pours a hazy copper color with a fluffy beige head that leaves plenty of lacing.  Smells of browned apples and yeast.  tastes of both with added notes of grass and hops.  Nice.

Bottle thanks to hbmason...thanks Tim! - Pours deep amber with a foamy, off-white head. Aroma is sweet, dark fruit with a bit of lemon, booze, and real sweet malty notes. Sweet cherries come through in the taste, with big sweet malt, lemon, honey, and dark roast on the finish. Its a bit syrupy, and the fruity sweetness is a bit too much for my tastes. Still complex and interesting, this was just a little off the mark for me.
( 750ml bottle thanks to BA ballewblake) Pours opaque orange with nice head/lace. Nose of sour fruits, bready yeast. Taste of grapes, bread, alcohol, with a great creamy/oily finish.

Bottle courtesy of ballewblake.

Pours brown with an off-white head. Aroma is fruit and Belgian yeast with a little bit of tartness. Flavor is caramel malt and dark fruit. You get a little bit of tart fruit in the flavor as well as some Belgian yeast characters that you expect in a dubbel. Medium body and medium carbonation.

Bottle courtesy of Beerbill, with many thanks! Just love this beer, so so tasty. Pours a slightly murky reddish brown. Aroma strong of bread, yeast, sweet malts, and dark fruit.  Big dark fruit in the flavor--plum, fig, dark cherry and prune, all over a malty backbone.  Sweetness is mellow, however, not cloying, and reminiscent of a good aged port.  Lingering yeasty breadiness on the finish, and the slightest twinge of hops adding some bitterness.  Really tasty, good winter drink.

23rd October 2008. Very hazy amber brown beer. A good take on the Belgian style. A little sour, smooth, a little milk chocolate in the undertone. Some banana in the lead up to the dry slightly spicy finish. Well joined up.

Finishing up my weekend purchses from Captain Lawrence.  This abbey dubbel is a great escape from frigid temps outside.  Pours brown with large long lasting beige head.  tastes malty, slight plum, with good carbonation.  Very good example of belgian american fusion.
bottle thanks to zdk9 on ba.  deep amber with a white head.  nose is yeast, light fruits and spices.  nice on the palate, very smooth spicy yeast flavor and a semi hot finish.

Bottle thanks to Hogtownharry. A murky, cloudy brown pour unleashes a frothy and long lived beige cap. Nose of plum and yeast, a bit of barnyard, caramel malts, toffee, a bit toasty. Tastes sweet. Of sugar plum and caramel, with dark bready flavours and milk chocolate, with a tame but present hoppiness. Creamy and full flavoured finish has lingering sweetness with balancing hoppiness. Good. Thanks Harry!

Bottle courtesy of ballewblake. Hazy copper orange color. Large Belgian fruit smell with an earthy spice aroma. Taste is of a lighter bitter that has grainy roots. Finish is a little sour but not by much.

750 ml bottle courtesy of either TheEpeeist or LilBeerDoctor. Thanks, guys! Pours a nice dark dulled amber, a bit brighter around the edges, pretty hazy, with a very large light brown/tan head, laces ok, very good retention though. Aromas are a nice vanilla, brown sugar, caramel, a light duller Belgian yeasty spice, apples, banana, delicate with a touch of cake. Initial is medium bodied, fruity with apple, pear, banana esters taking up residence. Some light brown sugar, cake, and vanilla in a small amount come in, a decent yeasty spice, a bit dulled, with fruits coming in stronger further into the body. To me, this is a lighter bodied dubbel, maltiness comes towards the backend, caramel, cereal, and a pretty noticeable bitterness on the backend. Not overly boozy, spice starts to permeate a bit more. Not a bad Dubbel overall, although Id have liked a little more life and body. A bit toasty, fruity, pretty good though overall.

2009 Bottle - Thanks corey70! - Pours a ruddy amber with a massive lt beige head...aroma is tart dry fruit and molassas malt, some yeasty esters...flavour is dry, roast meat, copper, some bubble gum and bitter grain...brown sugar malt yet still fairly dry, slightly astringent...
Got this 750ml @ Whole Foods, Bowery.  Pour is chestnut brown with some mega frothy white head atop.  Smooth caramel and slight burnt hay notes.  Soft on the palate.  Good.

nothing too special here. i almost wish i did age it instead of drink it right away. brown in color, tiny little head, minimal carbonation. sugary, yeasty, and some fruits on the nose. hard to pinpoint the taste, i would say molasses or maple syrup mixed with some sort of dried fruit. sugary and thick almost to the point where it turned me off. not a bad brew, i was just expecting something a little different.
Bottle.  Slightly cloudy amber with a thin even white head.  Smooth burnt caramel aroma, light Belgian yeast component.  Smooth taste, simply sweet and grainy, light yeasty flavors.  Pretty nice.
Bottle, brown sugar color with 1" tan foam, aroma is sweet and malty, flavor has a good smokey chocolate and spice character with some stewed fruit, finish is light and dry
A typical dubbel,this one is nothing spectacular but its not  disappointing either.
Special thanks to JMFG.  Raisins, brown sugar and a slight alcohol kick.  Flavor is fairly sweet but not off turning.  Very good.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2010 2006 750ml Bottle courtesy of ElJefe. Consumed at a Rochester Gathering August 2009. Mahogany color with a thin cream head. Aroma is very fruity. Plums and figs, smooth and tasty. 7/3/7/4/17

2010 750ml bottle from BOTW consumed right after purchase.  The color matches my prior notes as a rich mahogany with a spotty head of white cream.  Aroma is lightly nutty, and rich dark fruits that have turned alcoholic.  Nice stuff.  Flavors are much the same as the bouquet. Ripe fruit is very full bodied and a little sweet to go along with the dull alcohol to form a sophisticated and complex.

Draught on 25th July 2009 at Ginger Man NYC. Brown in colour with thin off white head of foam. Malt very much in evidence with berry fruit to the fore. Some background caramel; quite a lot of spice (cinnamon and nutmeg) in evidence; pungent to dry finish.

Bottle at the RB Rochester Gathering, Aug. 30/ 09. Thanks, ElJefe!  Poured a dark brown with an off white head. The nose is spicy, and malty with yeast to it. Flavor followed similarly. This is a nice rich double, that has quite a bit of depth.

Bottle at the RB Rochester Gathering, Sept. 09. Thanks, ElJefe! Is this what ElJefe bills as a light beer?  Light brown with reddish highlights.  Unfiltered.  Palate is sweet and sugary - brown sugar.  Nose is toffee.  Caramel in palate as well as dark fruit.  Neutral finish.  Nice!

Draft at Rattle N Hum. Pours a somewhat hazy red brown/amber witha  fluffy offwhite head. Nose is plums and distant raisins, caramel and maple. On taste, mildly roasty beneath the caramel notes and dark fruits. Pretty decent and fresh tasting for a Dubbel.

75 cl bottle at the RB Rochester Gathering, Sept. 09. Thanks, Eljefe. Dark amber color with lace. Fruity aroma with figs, raisins, and strong fruitiness. Very interesting flavor of sweet caramel, smoke, wood; rather stout-like. Complex, though maybe slightly confused, and interesting. A bit too light-bodied and fruity, but decent.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, garthicus, blankboy & tupalev - blankboys bottle. Hazy reddish-orange with a thin beige head. Aroma is mild but sweet with malt and dried fruit. Flavour follows, with some yeasty/estery edges, and a slightly herbal finish. Alcohol is noticeable but restrained. Nice stuff.
BCTC.  Reddish brown with ring.  Spicy nutty fruity soy sauce aroma.  Caramel candy sugar spicy soy sauce dark fruit.  Pretty decent.  Im not a fan of dubbels.

Pours dark red/light brown a dirty head. The nose is malty, nutty, with some nice ripe fruit character. A nice fruity malty flavor with just a hint of yeast character and alcohol. Easy to drink. Good stuff.

750 ml bottle.  Pours a ruby brown in color with an off white foamy head.  Aroma is spicey and fruity - plums.  Flavors are sweet, sugary, fruity - plums, banana.  Other notes include yeasty bread and cereal grains.  Body is medium and finish is smooth.
Draft. Pours amber red with a thin head. Sweet aroma of fresh fruits and spices. The flavor has sweet malt, fresh fruits, spices, and banana bread. Very tasty.

st vincents dubbel
somewhat cloudy orange, rocky beige head.
candied fruit aroma, peach and some malt. similar candy-like flavor, very fruity. sour finish with a hint of metal.
a bit thin and over-carbonated.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2010 I appreciate how well they where able to copy the "belgian" style (I wouldnt have been able to tell it wasnt from a belgian brewery if I hadnt already been aware).  Amber with small foamy head.  Spicy, cinnamon notes and a light mouthfeel but rich in flavor.  Malts and some alcohol in the backtaste.  
update: tried the 07 bottle shared by Eugene. toffee, creamy brown pour. pruney and fruity very aroumatic and tart.

Bottle courtesy of MCLK. Poured amber with small white head. Nose was sweet malt and spice, citrus, banana and slight alcohol. Flavor was sweet, booze, belgian yeasty spice, rich malt. Very nice dubbel.

Shared by unnamed soul at Stone Sourfest.  Orange-amber in the glass.  Nose is sweet and smooth, with a definite hint of cat pee.  Taste is sweet with a flat bounce on the tongue and mouth.  Warm and full.

bottle thanks to biggness (BA)Mahogany, nice foamy cream colored head, long-lasting. Nose is so delicate... sweet malts, raisin, plum, pepper, hop that recalls a wet forest in the middle of Autumn. All of this rolls on under the faint presence of cognac. Some of this in the flavor, though its more simple and alcohol-driven. Moderate body, nice cognac and almond finish. Delicious stuff, ultra-balanced and drinkable.

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2009 On tap at Rattle N Hum (Midtown, NYC): Pours a  deep ruby. Tastes of roasted pine, caramel and a variety of other tastes that I cant quite distinguish. Unfortunately not as delicious as Xtra Gold but this full-bodied beer still ranks as damn good. #052 on 07072009, DG.

Tap at the brewery for the release of the 4th vintage of this brew.  Pours a hazy brown caramel color with a medium white head.  Light booze, grain, plums, and caramel on the nose.  A bit gummy and sweet, with bananas and plums.  Finishes a touch hot and malty.  Also had a chance to try some of an 06 bottle that one of the guys from BA shared and it just blew the new release away and has me thinking Ill be sitting on these bottles for a few years.  Rating for the new offering  7 4 7 3 16. Bumping the aroma up to a 9 for the 06 though  full of caramel, toffee, and not a hint of alcohol or anything off.  Just gorgeous.

Amber pour, becoming a rich, slightly hazy mahogany in the glass, with a thick, lasting tan head.  Malt-based aroma, significant caramel here. Flavor is very malty, focusing on raisins and figs. The first few sips suffered from a sharp, somewhat oxidized off-note, but this quickly faded. As the glass continued, a spicy aromatic-bitter element somewhere between cardamom and mint entered in, especially towards the finish, and provided nice balance to the malt backbone. Medium to full body, very smooth, distinctly warming.
Bottle. Great beer! Flavor is complex and delicious, aroma is appropriate. This beer can get you drunk. Great beer from a great brewer.

I was incredibly surprised by this really nice beer. Bordering on a sour in terms of complexity and fruit. Add in a little nuttiness and you get this beer. Fruit is the red fruit variety like cherry and some plum. Aroma is wild belgian yeast. Finish leaves a bit of sweetness.

Bottle bonused from Yobdoog and shared at tasting.  Thanks!  Pours caramel colored with a medium lived beige head.  Smell is caramel and raisin with a touch of faint alcohol.  Taset is burnt raisin, a touch of alcohol, smooth caramel and a bit sweet after it warms up thought.  Not bad.

750 mL bottle courtesy of Alraomon. Pours a slightly hazy red color with floaties. Good head retention and lacing. Very earthy, malty aroma with a bit of a tart finish. Some fruit notes as well... citrus, grape and berry. Taste is toffee, candi sugar, earthiness, vanilla, grape, berries. Herbal notes as well.
Bottle from the limited release. Wonderful! Lots of flavor. One of the Breweries best!

Very pleasant beer. High drinkability. Compares nicely to most Belgian dubbels. No flavor jumps out at you, to my taste it is rather neutral. I usually dont like drinking Belgians with food but I think this would pair with almost anything.

Bottle from the Otown throwdown.  Deep copper color wtih a good sized white head.  Tons of fruit and malt up front on the nose with some woody and vanilla notes.  Flavor has some sweetness, syrup, brown sugar, and a nice element of bitterness lends balance.  Nice.

C&PLYFOTD: Bottle, courtesy jdubFL. Hazy copper pour, big fluffy white head and creamy lacing. Rich dark fruits in the nose, some chocolate, slight oak and vanilla. Flavor has some dark fruit with slight chocolate, but kinda muted overall. Full-bodied, feels lacking though, as the nose has a lot more promise than the flavor.

Thanks to Swolf3 for this bottle. Pours dark copper brown with a tall smooth beige head. Estery spiced nose, hints of fig and a soft alcohol heat to it. Body was airy and dry, felt like the water was pretty soft, pretty airy overall. Finish has a soft oak flavor and slight berry and anise flavor staying behind.

750ml bottle via trade a long, long time ago.  Pours a deep murky brown with a slight ruby hue.  A beige ring left a touch of lacing.  Big nose of dark fruits (figs, dates, raisins, plums) also light Belgian funk.  Sweet and fruity flavor, one of the better Dubbels out there IMO.

My bottle (750ml) shared with HogTownHarry, garthicus, GregClow & tupalev -- courtesy of my Summer Secret Santa 2008. Pours a murky orange-amber with an orange-amber with a large rocky off-white head. Subtle aroma is yeasty along with caramel malt, dark fruit and light herbal hops. Flavours sweet and malty along with yeast, brown sugar, light hops and dark fruit. Some alcohol but pretty well hidden. Average bodied. Quite good.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2009 Bottle (750ml) Shared by blankboy with me, garthicus, GregClow and tupalev.  Murky brown with an average creamy beige head (4-).  Lighly hoppy aroma - dry herbal bitterness - plus light sweet malt and, weirdly, latex paint.  The taste is herbal, mildly sweet, with dusty-dry bitter yeast, and a hint of celery.  Average body, no alcohol to speak of - a subtle, solid, but not amazing example - frankly, its more bitter and herbal than I recall a dubbel ever being.

Appearance:  almost clear light brown with dark amber accents. Very large soft frothy cloud like head. Fragmental lace. Aroma:  slightly creamy front with light hint of spice and zestiness. Brown malts sitting below. Fairly ordinary nose. 6- Flavor/Palate:  full bodied with lighter sides. Simplicity going into complexity. Frontal light brown malt character flowing, merging with slight funk of spice and citrus ending fuller with drying woody alcohol notes. Bottom sweetness paired with slight woody hints, peppery top, even earthy. Strong Old Ale that you should submerged into one.

Bomber courtesy of Toncatcher at the BA Numbskull line tasting. Pours an amber color with a white head. The aroma was lightly spicy and fruity. The flavor was similarly fruity with added rock candy, sweet berries and sweet melons. The mouthfeel was light and sweet. Overall: A very nice addition to the line tasting. Thanks Dennis.

Bottle shared with Hogtown Harry, Blankboy, GregClow, and Garthicus, courtesy of Blankboy.  Mild oak, malt, fruit in aroma - quite sweet.  Dark golden brown, small white head.  Great taste - alcohol, malt, fruit, hops.  Sharp taste, even some leather in there.  Excellent, right on style.

Thanks to HopHead84 for this brew. Pours cloudy caramel brown with a big, off-white head, good lace. Smells funky sweet malty. Tastes funky sweet malty, raisins and overripe red fruits. Full body, good smooth carbonation.

Blankboys bottle, shared with HogTownHarry, Tupalev and GregClow. Appearance: Brown/red HUGE head. Aroma: Cranberry, malt, yeast with a blackcurrant notes. Flavour: Blackberry, malty, alcohol and a yeast finish. Not bad at all.

Hazy dark pour, brown with a red tint.  Some sediment in the glass.  Nice dark tan-greyish head and good lacing on the glass.  Fruity cherry and apple aroma.  Funky with some yeast and a good amount of malt.  Very sweet, perhaps a bit too much for me. Fruity with cherry and apple.  Hints of chocolate and bitter hops to finish.  A touch of sourness.

Deep red coloured body with amber highlights and a thinnish tan head. Aroma of malt, caramel and some good light fruits. Medium-bodied; Strong assertive malts and a nice spicey flavour, tucked in with some lighter fruits and a tiny bit of hops. Aftertaste shows some alcohol, nuts and a bunch of malt. Overall, a good beer - definitely worth trying it if you can find it! I sampled this 750 mL bottle purchased from K&E Discount Liquor in New Paltz, New York on 09-May-2008, sampled on 26-November-2008.

Medium brown hazy pour.  Nice big bubbly off-white head. Bottle thanks to dchmela.  Dang, this was good.  I often find dubbels too sweet, but this was complex and tasty in all its malty sweetness.  Definitely big malt profile, but tons of fruit... figs, apples, raisins, even stewed apricots, perhaps. Earthy. Toasty caramel.  Brown sugar. Pralines. Deliciousness.
750ml bottle courtesy of Swolf3, thanks Steven. Nice dark murky brown. Sweet toasty aroma and a little smokey. Sweet flavor as well, a little spicy. Pretty good
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: 750ml bottle, poured in a chimay glass, amber-brown hue, with a thick creamy tan-colored head, leaving some belgian laces, yeasty, fruity, raisiny, toasty malt nose, with a hint of wineyness, and funkiness, with some dried chocolatey coated raisins, with some sweet pruney, date, figgy fruitiness, with some nutmeg, clove, brown sugar spiciness in the aroma with a medium-bodied palate with a yeasty, sweet toasted, caramelized malt, fruity character of dried raisins, plums, dates, figs, with some light chocolatey pralines, brown sugar flavors, with notes of spicy nutmeg, a subtle liquorice, with a faint  wine oakiness, leading towards a warming, sweet malty, chocolatey finish.

This poured deep copper in color with a thick head.  The nose gave off aromas of caramel apples, yeast, malt and dark fruit all with a sweet and sour element to it.  In the mouth it was medium-bodied and very well-balanced.  The sweetness, dryness, bitterness and carbonation are all complement each other well.  The only thing I wish this had more of would be flavor concentration in the midpalate.
A little darker than I expected. the flavor was sweeter than I expected or liked, lots of malts, not much in the way of balance.  Just too sweet and sugary.

750ml. Really not a fan of this style. Even the MS Matrisse didn’t do it for me (thanks Todd!). But I love this brewery, so here goes... Gusher. Figures. Pours lighter than expected. Thick, cloudy brown/maroon with a decent off white head. Aroma initially yields ligher fruit notes... freshly cut peaches and pear skin. Fruit leather and moist tobacco. A touch of wet leaf pile and earth.  Brown sugar and a bit of wet paper bag as well. As the beer opens, a blast of green apple with some mildly phenolic yeast hits the nose. Flavor is a balanced mix of malt and yeast. Brown sugar, caramel, fruit leather and tobacco. The yeast yields a bit of lacto creaminess on the tongue. Apple skin. Slightly earthy. Medium on the tongue with lively carbonation. Finish is rather lengthy, earthy, mostly dry with some tannic fruit skin. Definitely one of my more favorite examples of the style. Thanks Jonathan!

thanks nhorween. nice marroon brown color, not quite as dark as most dubbels i’ve had.  nice thin head. smell takes me back to belgium, some dark fruit aroma with fresh wood character, a little bit funky.  taste is a bit thin, then sweet and woody.  a bit more carbonated than i’d like for a dubbel, but it’s pretty well made altogether.  i agree with the description that it’d go well with food.

Draught @ Beer Table, Brooklyn. Pours a clear, dark red brown with just a bit of a head. Nose is licorice and dark fruits, a bit of caramelized brown sugar. Taste is much the same - yeast is subdued for the style, made up for by a pronounced licorice note, dark fruits and caramelized brown sugar, moving to a toasty bread crust as well. Mouthfeel is just a hair thin, medium to start with moderate carbonation, thinning out on the finish. There’s a definite dopplebock characteristic to this one as well, almost like a dubbel-bock. Clean where it should be spicy, licorice where there should be yeasty. Very interesting and different take on an abbey dubbel.

Large bottle. Poured a dark brown with an off white head. The nose is spicy, and malty with a belgian yeast to it. Flavor followed similarly. This is a nice rich double, that has quite a bit of depth for an american belgian beer. Nicely carbonated. The finish is a bit on the thin side, but that shouldn’t stop you from enjoying this very good beer.
A beautiful electric brown color topped by a tan head, this strong malty ale is creamy smooth, with a touch of caramel and wild fruit flavor running low on the radar.

Bottle.

Deep red-brown with a fluffy large tan head. Lots of dried fruit on the nose, apple cider. Malt-heavy and on sweet side (brown sugar) but pleasantly so, this one turned out to be a very nice surprise.  For whatever reason, I actually like the sweetness here.

Bottle: I’m surprised it took me so long to rate this! Pours a brown/auburn with a strong, creamy, thin tan head. The aroma is sweet with dark fruits- maple, fig, brown sugar, dark Belgian malts and a buttery toffee/chocolate note. Creamy on the palate. The flavor is initially sweet with maple and brown sugar, along with sweet raisiny notes as well. Then it’s followed by some toasted, dark Belgian malt character, as well as a subtle fruit note of dark berries? Toward the finish there’s a nuance of smoked (peat-like) character with a mildly bitter/roasted finish. A balanced and well executed example of the style. (Which many American brewers tend to make too sweet, but not this one)
Hazy brown pour with fluffy tan head.  Malty aroma.  Flavor is malty, fruity, and very earthy.  Nice bitter finish!

Bottle from the Captain Lawrence brewery. The aroma is malty and fruity. Very rich and a good sipping beer. I shared thebottle with a friend and wouldn’t want to drink the whole thing alone. It’s good but probably wouldn’t go out of my way to buy again
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: Bottle.  Pours a cloudy brown with a thick tan head.  Aroma of roasted nuts, Belgian yeast, with light fruits (apple, pear) in the background.  Flavor of roasted malts, roasted nuts, fig, and light fruits.  Smooth creamy palate.  An excellent American-brewed dubbel.  One of my favorite Captain Lawrence beers.

Bottle. Aroma of rich caramel malt Belgian yeast, toffee, molasses, prunes, raisins, liquorice, all in all simply awesome. Flavor malty, earthy yeast, sweet, but always a dry, gritty sweetness, fruits, earth. Fantastic.
Another lovely drinking Belgium from this brewery. Yeasty and malty aroma.  Full mouthfeel.  Sweet whipped up maltiness, with building waves of moderate bitterness.

750ml a ways back a bonus in a trade.  Shared with my gf cyn.  Pours dark amber with a tan head.  Nose is really sweet and very much like a dessert liquor.  Taste is sweet and full of a nice rich caramel.  Nice beer overall a great Dubbel.

2008, 750ml.  Chestnut/mahogany pour with a fine and soapy cream colored head.  Caramel, toffee, dates, figs, and toast all over the aroma.  Smells great.  Apple juicy middle to the nose, finishes with alcohol burn in the nostrils.  Flavor is very appley, lots of the toffee goes away.  Toast and carmel are in the back with the alcohol.  Smooth finish with some residual bitterness.  Soapy mouthfeel.  Well crafted.

2008 - 750 bottle poured into a trappist glass has a  brown amber color and a head that diminished quickly. aroma has dark fruit, heavy malt, yeast, banana, and alcohol. mouth feel is on the lighter side with plenty of carbonation. flavor is loaded up with malt and yeast, figs, plumb, raisin, and brown sugar. has a richness and a touch of sour but lacks the intensity found in many other CL. beers. alcohol is a little too upfront and takes from the flavors a bit here.

750 ml bottle.  Pours a hazy brown with some reddish highlights when held against light.  Moderate-large linen white head that faded to a ring by the first quarter of the glass and left very little lace.  Strong aroma of yeast with some malt and alcohol also present.  Light sourness in the aroma as well.  The flavor is also yeasty, although there is more malt present than in the aroma.  I really didn’t get the fruitiness that others have expressed.  Medium-full bodied.  A solid brew, but not one of my favorites from CL.

Pours a slightly hazy reddish-brown colour with a puffy tan head that fades almost immediately to a pencil-thin ring. The nose is aromatic, sweet, and yeasty, with notes of cherry, piping hot phenols, light caramel, brown sugar, BOOZE and dark fruits. The flavour is very malty and fruity with chewy caramel, overripe darkfruits, nuts, brown sugar and vanilla. There are some phenolic flavours coming through to, though mostly in the finish. The palate is initially full and slick, with effervescent carboination, finishing dry.

Pours a semi cloudy redish amber color which had a thick head initially but faded rather quick. The nose has a strong nutty and bready aroma with hints of brown sugar and dark fruit, but the nuts seem to overpower the smell a bit. The initial flavor was very bitter and left a nice impression on the palate. The after taste is nutty with the sweet finish making the beer more enjoyable. I enjoyed the beer alot since it had just the  right amount of carbonation.

Thanks for sharing Yaniv!  Dark reddish brown with a big light tan head.  Round soft dark fruit.  Prune.  Dark fruit.  Not full, not sweet, not alcohol.  Soft carbonation, not watery.  Sweet malt, dark fruit.  A bit creamy.  Small alcohol.  Not tons of character.   A small amount of roast.  A bit tannic perhaps?  Slightly lacking a big punch, but not a bad beer by any stretch.

Bottle.  Not one of my favorite CL bottles, maybe my least.  Pours a dark ruby brown body.  Aroma is chewy fruit, some caramel malt and sweet.   Flavor is chewy a good mouthful of malty dark fruit filled flavors.  Ill have to revisit this bottle.

750ml bottle courtesy of Footy. Sweet barley and bready yeast. Amber body with big beige head and good lacing. Flavor has a caramel sweetness moderate with a moderate sweet sour to it. Good sipping brew not to sweet and not an overpowering sour or spice to it. Thanks Rudy finnaly got around to drinking this one.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2011 bottle @ Carolina Crew get together. Provided by emacgee & aubreya. Good aroma, sweet, fruity, sugary. Brownish orange color, good head & lace. Sweet flavor, fruity, apple, lemon. yeasty spice. Medium body, creamy mouthfeel, bitter finish. Tasty, nice flavor was very nice. on tap at hopheads craft beer market. phone dying...
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: 2007 bottle - Rich amber color with a larger than average off-white head.  Aroma is quite sweet with some brown sugar, raisins, and light summer & vinous fruits.  Flavor has a nice sugary malt backing with that distinct CL yeast, fruits, and a nice hint of hops coming through at the end.  Pleasant feel - as always, Scott comes through with a really nice beer in a style that is full of mediocre brews.  Wonderful!

Bottle shared by ethan and aubrey at the CC gathering.  Man, I havent been drinking too many dubbels or tripels lately so this really hit the spot.  Very nicely balanced with fruits, spices, and chewy malts. Not too sweet either.  Another great one from the Captain!

Shared by emacgee at the Carolina crew gathering. Man, now this is a tart and fruity dubbel. Its got amazingly lively carbonation, and manages to avoid the dull sticky character that a lot of American renditions fall into. Lively with spice, yeast, and fruits, complex but balanced by a dry and hoppy finish.

Thanks to hophead 75 for this one. Pours a nice ruddy reddish brown with a 1-2 finger creamy tan head. The nose is sweet, fruity, a little alcohol coming in, earthy. Nice flavor, sweet, fruity, Belgian yeast, meaty, distinctly a dubbel but a good one at that. Very nice carbonation. CL has yet to let me down.

Bottle from Mystery swap 3.0. Pours a hazy reddish-brown color with a thin white head.  Aroma of caramel. over ripe fruits, roasted malt and yeast. Flavor is sweet with over ripe fruits, caramel and roasted malt. Has a light, hoppy bitter finish.

Thanks to bluemeow76 for bringing a bottle home from a trip. The beer is a dark reddish-brown color with a thick and foamy light beige head that recedes slowly. Slick, patchy lacing on the glass. The aroma consists of malt, ripe fruit and yeast with some spices. Medium body with flavors of malt, dark fruit and yeast along with some hops. The finish is smooth and fruity with a mild spice and yeast aftertaste. Pretty good overall.

Thanks to beerlando for this. Pours a watery red with a thin white head. Aroma is sour cherry, malt, caramel malt. Taste is tart cherry, malt, and raisin. Really a neat taste. Hoppy tart finish. Really nice.

thnks to beerlando for sharing this! Caramelly malt aromas.  Pours an amber brown with a thin white head.  Super malty flavors, very caramelly, with some brown sugar, rich flavors but very light on the palate.

Pours a very cloudy, dark caramel brown.  A foamy, off-white head produces scattered, jagged lines of lacing.  The aroma is big-time malty, with layers of caramel, nougat, and a touch of chocolate providing a deep, sweet base for a potent blend of dark and light raisons.  Smells very inviting, with the golden raisons adding just the slight twangy sourness that the malty notes call for.  The flavor follows suit, with velvety layers of nougat and caramel malts working hand in hand with the sweet and sour fruit.  Plums make an appearance, adding further depth. Medium-full body, with a smooth but sugary mouthfeel.  Great beer.  One of the better Dubbels Ive had, for sure.  Captain Lawrence continues to impress.

Cloudy copper color with a fizzy fast head. Caramelized sugary aroma with an herbal presence in the background. Huge sweet malt flavors up front, with alot fo sugary graininess coming up behind. A little harsh with alcohol showing.  There are also some light berry-like fruits, perha s cherries or gooseberries in character.

Bouteille de 750 ml partagée lors dune dégustation Ratebeer Montréal chez Glouglouburp. Arôme: Odeur de raisins et de prunes. Apparence: La couleur est ambrée voilée. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de caramel et de petits fruits foncés. Longue durée de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture huileuse.Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence dalcool en arrière goût. (Rating #1598)

Aroma of sour cherries, plums and some honey, cloudy reddish brown, small off-white head. A fine malt taste, gorgeous hop backing. Medium bodied, very well balanced, lovely mouth feel. Great! Thank You rudolph.

Objectively speaking:
An original dubbel that is just as captivating as their tripel.


I like:
Gorgeous aroma. Incredible black grape concentration. Pure black grapes, seed included! Ive never encountered the like in beer. Captivating cognac notions. Plummy. Very pleasant and perfumey. Juicy by its mere fruitiness. Gentle cherry notes in the background. Surprisingly growing bitterness, serving as a firm backbone and limiting the sweetness growth. Toasty. Cleansing carbonation, very active, almost biting. Tiny grap skin astringency.





I dislike:
I loved it. That aroma is as idiosyncratic as it gets. I just did not find that its fruit intensity was as vibrant and vital in mouth and in terms of looks, some head would help.

Nov. 2007 - Thanks to eaglefan538 for sharing this one. Pour was dark amber, frothy head but quickly dispersing, some lacing. The aroma was dark fruits. The flavor was dark fruit (plums, raisins). Mouthfeel was bubbly and airy, yet still sticky and thick. Not bad.

750ml bottle and served in my Big Karmeliet glass: A  mahogany hue with a lasting frothy off-white hue and very good lace. The aroma has notes of Holy Phenols and alcohol along with some prune, fig, dark candy sugar, earthy and peaty yeast esters and some band-aid too. The taste is luckily better than the nose with lots of dark sugars and fruits over a layer of yeasty goodness support by some spice and wood. Got a soft carbonated mouth feel with a chalky finish. Not too bad at all and very drinkable.

Bottle shared at the Cleveland tasting. I do not know who. The Captain made a pretty big showing though at this shindig! Well, I like the sweet and malty ones, so this one was right up my alley! A lively little brew...Kind of tingly. Flavors of apples and grapes, citrus and plums. I found this almost had a slightly sour taste to it. Would love to see how this one ages.

330 ml draught, Barcade. No head. Brown colour. Subdued raisiny aromas. Smooth texture with little carbonation. Raisiny flavours. Hints of port. Balancing hop bitterness. Oxidized notes. Powdery and a touch of dark malts.

750mL Bottle. Noses forward in plums and yeast minerals. A complex, but maybe confused aroma. Seltzer water over grains. A mature alcohol fruit, if tangy. Interesting, lightly spicy and moderately inviting. Pours a reddish-brown, half-hazed with a growing prosperous head in silky tan. Flavor is rich, but bites a little. Theres a curt tannic ring to the beer that ebbs acidic. This carries over a bed of mature dry fruits, raisin and Frangelico. Complexity and spice, with a high yeast profile. Rather signature of Abbey styles. Theres a bit of a battle for the lead character of the beer. Mature fruit, sustained spice, or alcohol sugars. Hops give a beautiful afterglow in heavenly resin that just rounds the beer delightfully. Im confused by the mid-palate of the beer. Theres a lot going on and the sensation is perplexing. The carbonation is extremely soft and diffusive. However, theres a palpable astringency to the body that throws me off throughout the beer. This keeps it down a little. Nonetheless, its the most faithfully produced example of the style, with remarkable depth and complexity, yet maintaining drinkability in its freshness and conditioning. Interesting.

750ml bottle probably from maxxdaddy..... pours an opaque dark caramel browm with persisting off-white head.... aroma of assertive dark fruit and caramel sugars and some breadiness... flavors of sacharine dark fruity malts and a little yeast with a sugary afternote.... a fairly sweet dubbel very big on the malt.
Orange, amber colour with a beige head. Malty, caramel and cookie sweet aroma with notes of some fruity and alcohpol sweetness. Malty, caramel sweet flavor with dried dark fruit notes.

Pours out moderately light hue of cloudy brown with a moderate fluffy head. Aroma is of dark fruit, yeast and some caramel. Taste is of dark fruits, fig, date, caramel, slight roasted malt and a lingering sweetness on the finish.

2006 Bottle courtesy of golubj; poured a slighlty murky, brownish color.  Aroma of roasted malt, slightly soury fruit, cocoa, and pit fruit.  Flavor got better with a little bit of warmth.  Flavor of fruit, pit fruit, caramel, roasted malt and a decent hop finish.  There was also some banana/yeast and sour elements.  Pretty good for the style.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2008 2006 Bottle.  Muddy brown pour with some thin off-white head.  Light roasted aroma, dark fruit, yeast, a little fruity tartness.  Flavor is dominated by lightly roasted malt, some dark fruit and chocolate are in there as well.  Sort of yeasty, off-maltiness finish.

Bottle: pours a cloudy burnt orange with a long lasting frothy head, sweet aroma that you expect from a dubbel, taste is burnt caramel and some dark fruits.  Not a top of the line dubbel but I wouldnt mind having this one again.
750 ml bottle shared with padrefan98.  Lighter than I had expected from a dubbel.  Nice head.  Aromas were fruity and bready.  Flavor was molasses and some dusty earthy spices.  Pretty tasty stuff.

25 oz bottle, via Dickinsonbeer.  Pours a slightly hazy amber brown body under a small beige head, fairly light carbonation.  The nose is fruity and yeasty with a little bit of an alcohol vapor.  Actually fairly light on the aroma.  The flavor is fruity and a little husky with some chocolate and cherry skins.  Finishes with lots of fluffy belgian yeast and some alcohol.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied, a little more watery in texture than I prefer in a Dubbel.  Moderate fizzy carbonation.  This was pretty decent overall, but it didnt really do it for me really.  Im not even sure why though.

Not too much on the aroma and the hops have pretty much faded out.  Nice deep copper color with a decent sized head.  Flavour is outstanding on this with huge amounts of caramelization.  So much so that it seems more like an old ale or English barley wine.  Some raisen and light burnt toffee notes.  Slight green apple character with a certain amount of oxidation present.  I loved the huge amount of caramelization, but it is getting on in years.

2006 bottle.  Poured deep caramelly-brown with a lovely initial cap of beige head.  The aroma picked up lightly sour dark fruit skins and Belgian yeast upfront with toasty aged caramel and nutty notes behind.. just a touch too sour for my liking.  The flavor had hefty doses of warm caramel and darker, raiseny fruits at the core, with brown sugar and a bit of molasses integrated in there.. light herbal bitterness graced the edges, but seemed like it receded greatly in the last couple years.. sour plum skins and lighter vinegar show, especially on the back-end.. mighty tasty, and delightfully complex.  Medium-bodied, warm, and well-composed on the palate.  Great one!

750ml Bottle

Bottled: 2006

Ive been sitting on this bottle for a little over a year now. A quiet pfftt as I pop the top. An aggressive pour brought about a thick ring and island of head swirling around the glass. The head that did form disappeared quickly leaving a thing ring. The body is a somewhat murky reddish-brown. 

The aroma, although not bad, just doesnt seem to jive with the style. Caramel malt is present and forms a solid base. We get offline with a big nose of green apple along with some other orchard fruit its hard to put my finger on. The caramel is deep and rich. 

Flavor starts off a little shyly but before you know it caramel and spicy alcohol come along. There seems to be some of those orchard fruits in the flavor as well and they just dont get along with the caramel sweetness. Things seem to weaken again on the swallow. Jut not a very good example of a dubbel. Alcohol seems to be a little too prominent.

The body doesnt stand up to what a dubbel should be either. Too thin and slightly watery. Could stand a burst of carbonation on the tongue.

Not a very drinkable beer. The flavor just isnt where it should be. One glass is enough for me.

A real disappointment from Captain Lawrence. Everything else Ive sampled from them has been top notch. Unfortunatley, this offering falls far short.

2/3/08

I recently drank my last bottle of the 2nd batch. One reason I am beginning to love American Belgain style brews. Aroma is very nice candi sugar and lots of caramel malts and some spices. Taste has much of what aroma has including some dark fruits like raisins and figs, dates, plums and some baked bread. Nice full body and well balanced.

Bottle thanks to a trade with dmac621, thanks Dave. Captain Lawrence has continued to impress. It has certainly become one of my favorite breweries. This dubbel is so tasty. The carbonation was good. Some caramel and brown sugar. A little yeast. Very good.

Dark orange-brown in colour, small white coloured head, light lacing.  The aroma was of apples, cherries, some yeast, light alcohol, brown sugar.  The flavour is lightly sweet, mild fruit, light yeast, some dark malts, very light chocolate.  Mildly sweet mouthfeel, medium body, medium carbonation.  Finishes sweet, lingering.  A sweet dubbel, good balance, quite nice.
750ml bottle shared by <a
href=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?U target=blank>rudolf, thanks Rudy.
Opened on December 1, 2007.
Vintage 2006.

[881-20071201] 750mL (Xmas Party 2007, beerhugger & guests; Vintage 2006). Boozy fruit apple aroma with toasted malt. Hazy, red brown body with a medium-lasting foamy off-white head. Tart cherry pie malt flavour has sweet filling and is a little grainy throughout. Medium body has some tartness. Wow what a lovely aftertaste.

Icing sugar, brown sugar, and plenty of dark pit fruit in the nose.  Hazy brown body is topped by a decent, fine bubbled, tan head that recedes to a partial cover with some sudsy lacing.  Very sweet round malt flavour has plenty of dark fruitiness and brown sugar.  Light bitterness and perhaps a lightly tart underlying twang.  Medium body with moderate carbonation.  Doesnt really grab me but it is certainly decent.  Bottle sampled with Beershine and Oakes.

750mL bottle from my summer Secret Santa, puzzl, thank you sir.  this isnt as dark as Id like a dubbel to be.  Clear orange with some light reddish highlights and a one finger beige head, pretty decent retention.  Aroma is quite fruity with figs and raisins.  Lots of Belgian yeast is present along with some tangy sweet toffee.  The back end has some spicy alcohol and faint roast.  Flavor is again quite fruity and tangy. I think there may have been a hint of tobacco as well.  Semidry tangy finish with again, the hints of roast.  Not particularly to style, though there are some elements of a dubbel, and still quite nice.  Full body with light to moderate carbonation.  Another winner from Captain Lawrence.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text:
Bottle. Pours a dark orange-brown body with a small off-white covering. Aroma is quite rich - notes of cherry, caramel, and butterscotch. Flavour has some nice flowing malts with cherry and plum overtones. Finishing with some toffee and butterscotch flavours. Super.
 Tasted in December 2007.
Poured a nice brown/orange color with good head and great lacing.  Aroma was tons of dark fruits plums mostly.  Flavor was much the same some spices yeast in there as well.

Rating #1600 2006 750 ml bottle (old label) from beastiefan2K; Nose of apple, caramel, and spices; cloudy brown with a medium, glass-lacing beige head; flavor of caramel, brown sugar, peppery spices, and light raisins. Good but not great!

Pours cloudy and caramel colored, with a generous and frothy beige head.
The finely dense foam recedes to almost full coverage on the surface, with some decent strings of lacework.
Aromatics lead off with toffee-laced bubblegum. Plenty of phenols and extremely fruity. Tangerines with red grapes step forward.
The mouthfeel is medium, with a fairly creamy profile. Carbonation is somewhat light for style.
The pallet is fruit-laden and caramel-like. 
A orange marmalade infused Sugar-Daddy.
Alcohol is barely noticable and only slightly warming.
Finishes with a firm bitterness and lingering tropical fruit.
Very tasty and drinkable, but some cocoa notes would add some depth.

From bottle, no 24 at Papsoes blindtasting. Pours hazy red towards brown and with lacing white head. Aroma is fruity, dried and slight wineous. Flavour is slight berry fruity, wineous and caramel malty. Solid flavour. Finish holds a canesugarish and towards dry woody note, finally a slight bitterness.

Pours an amber color with red highlights into the trappist glass with a huge, two inch head.  Scents of malt, dried fruit, toffee and brown sugar.  A very malty taste up front with a very chewy mouthfeel.  A slight sourness to finish with some vinegary flavors.

Pours with a nice frothy white head with slow and steady dissipation. Hazy, semi-opaque. Deep saturated red due. Candy sugar nose. Malty-sweet. Chewy, slightly sticky mouth. Bready taste: bread crusts.
Dark reddish-amber.  Dark malt - toffee, cherry, plum, earth and alcohol.  Fairly straightforward dubbel.  Dryish, slightly peppery finish.

Bottled. An unclear brown beer with a lazing beige head. The aroma is sweet with notes of over ripe fruits, prunes, and metal - somewhat oxidiced. The flavor is sweet with notes of prunes, oxidation, metal, and over ripe fruit as well as a light notes of alcohol, leading to a dry alcoholic finish. Thanks Papsoe for sharing.

#24 [Blind tasting session @ Papsoe 30-11-2007] Small beige fizzy head that mostly diminished. Hazy amber color. Good display of lacework. Rye bread, dried fruit, caramel, grain. Over the palate light notes of coffee, roasted malt and liquorish. Full bodied with an average carbonation. Moderated sweet flavor with light bitter notes. Dried fruity and lingering finish.
Bottle. A dark red beer with a beige head. The aroma and taste is of caramel malt, fruits and rye bread. Medium to full body with a light sweet alcoholic finish.

Bottle. Ratebeer Christmas in Oshawa, December 2007. Brown body, with a smallish beige head (3+). Big fruity aroma, pitted fruit not quite cherries. (7+) Sweet flavour has mild version of the same fruit character, underlying brown sugars and caramel malt. (7+) Smooth medium palate could use a touch more carbonation. (3+) Quite nice.

Bottle.
Hazy orange brown coloured with an off white head.
Sweet aroma of malts, rye rbead and dried fruits.
Flavour of malts, caramel, rye bread and dried fruits with notes of toasted bread.

Xmas in Oshawa.  Thanks!  Chestnut brown, thin white head.  Nose is caramel, bubblegum, yeast, fruit.  Nice & rich.  Flavor is caramel, yeast ,butterscotch, dark fruits.  Butterscotch at the finish grows and grows.  Some slight alcohol tingles.  Really nice but maybe a hint too much body.  Some cocoa in the finish.

2007-11-30, Papsøs Blind TastingHazy red-amber color; creamy head. A hint of oak and vanilla in the aroma. Medium body, with a fresh caramel flavor, milky, quite sweet, lightly oaked, correct bitterness, warming alcohol in the end; not complex enough. Very pleasant.

(Bottle 75 cl) Courtesy of kmweaver. Slightly hazy, orangey brown with a beige head. Aroma of fruit, a little wood and a whiff of yeast. Full body with rich, sweet, roasted malts. Lightly vinous with a little overripe fruit. Even notes of sherry. Subdued bitterness. Another elegant offering from Captain Lawrence. 301107

Bottle. Pours a hazy red-brown colour. Sweet aroma with dark fruits, roasted malt and alcohol. Good mouthfeel. Flavour is sweet with dark fruits, roasted caramel and malt, bitter hops, bits of chocolate and slight alcohol. Rather too sweet.

Dark brown  pour with a thin fleeting tan head.
Big malt and alcohol nose.
Lots of dried fruits in the flavor, accompanied by malts and alcohol in a complex blend.
Nice one.

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2008 deftim13 brought this 1 yr old bottle to the Lost Abbey Older Vis release.  Thanks Tim!  Dark amber.  1 yr old.  Medium bubbles.  Big head.  Champagne mouthfeel from heavier carbonation.  That was fun. A little tart finish.  Bill says it is the beginnings of an acetobacter infection.  Its barely noticable at this point.  A little orange peel bitterness.  Pretty easy to drink.  Was going to give it a 3.8, but my numbers added up to 3.7.
Rerate at Alesmith BA ON Release: 3.8

Bottle shared by sliffy. Hazy red pour with a fluffy white head. Aroma of light green hops, brown sugar, lemon zest and pale malt. Flavors of lemon, yeast, light banana, spices  , floral hops and caramel malt. Medium body sweet/tart/sour with a sweet/sour/dry finish. Excellent.

Bottle, nice clear dark amber with a beige head. Nice flowery, sorta hoppy nose - not phenolic or spicy. Caramel, then some tart pear-like character, berries, wood and light brown sugar. Medium/full bodied with moderate carbonation. Good head retention. Very nice stuff.

(11/3/07, 750ml bottle) Medium beige head, clear copper body, nice lacing.  Aroma is medium sweet, caramel, perfume, some raisin, alcohol.  Taste is moderately sweet, raisin/fig, some caramel, light cinnamon, berry.  Some alcohol.  Medium body.

Thanks for sharing Sick_boy.  Pours with a clear, deep red body topped by a thick, off-white head with a good amount of lacing.  Its slightly sweet and malty with notes of dark fruit and a grassy hoppy note.  Much more hoppiness showing through than expected.  The aroma is a little more floral.  Medium to full bodied, smooth and a touch tingly on the tongue.

Bottle: Pours a clear copper with a light tan head. Aroma, dark fruits, with some yeasty notes, leading to caramel and molasses. Flavor, fruity up front, followed by caramel and brown sugar, there is some citrus in the background with some light sourness, and a mild sweetness, kinda chewy on the palate, this stuff was really nice.

This opened up in my glass like several other great dubbels that I had tasted. It poured into a glorious head with a shaking skirt of bubbles. The first taste was like the last with dark maltiness and an interesting array of flavors to follow.

Bottle: Poured a medium brown color ale with a big foamy head with some good retention and some lacing. Aroma consist of sweet Belgian malt with some dry fruits characteristics such as dry figs and plums. Taste of sweet Belgian malt with some notes of dry fruits characteristics. Body is full with a creamy texture and some pretty good carbonation. I thought this was a bit too boozy overall to really enjoy on a regular basis thought.

Murky.  A bit of a boozy whiskey and brandy nose, containing candy sugar, heavy yeast phenols, and some fresh, crisp apples and brown sugar.  Even some smoky caramel around the edges (so it tastes a bit like caramel apples).  Thinner than expected, but I understand this isn’t a huge beer, but I did get more alcohol in the nose than I expected.  Finishes mildly lactic and sour.  It’s weird, different, and overall tasty.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2007 750 ml bottle. Pours a god looking amber with a great looking creamy head that lasts and lasts. Sweet aroma of yeast and sugar. Flavor is very sweet and yeasty with hints of a more sugary base lying beneath. This is one nice brew.

750mL bottle, more recent bottling (blue label), courtesy of argo0.  Thanks, Aaron!  Pours a bright, hazy yellow-amber color; light tan head with excellent, fine-bubbled lacing.  Plenty of green apples and biscuity malts in the aroma; soft brown sugar and mild citrus.  Fluffy, highly carbonated mouthfeel: brown sugar, mildly tart citrus, with some bananas and sticky sugar throughout; slightly muddled, with solid chewiness and a bit too much carbonation.  Lengthy, brown sugar and biscuity finish.

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2008 Poured from a 750.  Newest batch.  Semi-clear bronze pour.  Green apple, nectarine, cotton candy, banana and light spices on the nose; it has that pixie dust quality of sugary sweetness.  Different and forward.  Tastes of juniper, leafy green spice, and acerbic rasperries, leaning into cocoa dust and cedar bitterness.  Distant intimations of the more usual tones of bubblegum, honey, and banana are there, but only tangentially, while those leading characteristics are more peculiarly persistent and interesting.  Crisp, clean and subtle in the mouth; briskly carbonated but soft and smooth.  Blossoms with sweet floral and needly tones.  Very little is standard about this.  Intriguing.  Thanks for sharing, Aaron!

Bottle.  Pours a dark amber color with a medium-sized slightly off-white head.  Banana was the 1st component of the aroma I caught and it is combined with some yeast, caramel, some spices and some dark fruits.  Flavor was heavy with the malts, darker fruits, toffee and some slight spice.  A bit of the alcohol comes through, but far from over-powering.

Courtesy SoLan.  Pours a dark amber color, with a huge, fluffy, well-retained light tan head.  Smells of some sweet candy sugar, sweet malts, Belgian yeast, and sweet fruits.  Fairly standard aromas for this style.  The flavor was mostly sweet, some figs, bitter dark fruits, mild candy sugar, and even a hint of some tartness all formed the flavor profile.  Not overly complex, but a solid rendition of this style for an Ameican brewer.  Finishwas sweet fruits, and some sticky molasses.  Pretty solid from these guys again.

25.4 oz bottle, 2006.  Not quite clear, but dense brown with orange edges.  A bit of balsa head.  Vinous, raisin and yeasty brown sugar.  Chewy mocha and burnt sugar, hint of plum, then tobacco and sour celery.  Doesnt close the deal.

Poured a red amber color with a large, off white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of caramel malts, banana nut bread, dark fruits, and light spices.  Taste of various fruits (citrus and notes of dark), caramel malts, light toffee, yeast, with a bit of cocoa, and some alcohol in the finish.

750ml bottle-pours a creamy retaining tan head and brown with orangy/red color.  Aroma is sweet medium malt-caramel, some acidic/spices, yeast, some fruit, ginger.  Taste follows, secondary earthy hops, some alcohol.  Interesting interpretation of a Belgian style.  Although, like an Urthel.  OK effervescence.

(2006 Bottle)

Appearance: Pours a clear, dark brown body with a small, dense ecru head.

Smell: Soft, malty aroma of brown sugar and caramel, with maybe, just maybe a pinch of molasses. Hints of spiced dates.

Taste: Sweet, heavy maltiness upfront with flavors of caramel and dark brown sugar. Mildly doughy. Spiced, candied date fruitiness. Very faint bitterness perks up late in the taste. Wraps up with the warming, inviting presence of alcohol on the finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation. Somewhat chewy mouthfeel.

Drinkability: I usually can go either way with dubbels, but I cant help but find Saint Vincents Dubbel to be pretty likeable!

Porus a hazy brown with an ok head. The aroma is that of a bran muffin with maybe a few raisins thrown in for good measure. The flavor is a little hot. Youre tasting the alcohol more than youd expect from a beer thats 8% and fairly sweet from the malt. A little sticky.

Bottled 2006, Sampled September 2007
Pours with a frothy, initially three-finger thick, tightly beaded, tan colored head that sits atop a drab, opaque, dark plum colored beer, but which shows a brilliantly clear, bright cranberry color when held up to the light.  The aroma is quite fruity smelling, with notes of blackberries, sweet plums and cherries being noticeable as the beer sits on the table in front of me.  When I go in for a closer inspection of the nose, I get concentrated malt notes as well as the previously noticed fruit notes.  Aromas of caramelized malt, brown sugar, a lightly concentrated malt note that evokes thoughts of an umami-like savoriness, toasty grain, lightly-browned soda crackers make up the distinctly malt derived components.  The malt, obviously heavily influences the fruit aromatic components of this brew too.  The fruit character also yields aromas of raisins, prunes, concentrated-caramelized apples and a bright berry like note.  The aroma is quite nice and quite rich; I could certainly wish for a bit more spicy yeast influence, but it is really quite good.

Despite being fairly well carbonated, the beer has a soft creaminess to it up front.  The carbonation then kicks in and helps to lighten the beers effect on the palate as well as adding a zippy frothiness to the brew as it flows past the tongue.  It is fairly sweet and fruity tasting, though not overly so and in fact dries out to a soft sweetness after the first sip or so.  The finish is interesting though, with a definite dark malt influence that leans towards darkly browned toasted bread and even an astringency from the toasted influence.  This adds a bit of sharpness to the finish.   Speaking of sharpness there is a spicy note in the finish as well; flavor notes from higher alcohols, a touch of phenolics and ginger/clove like note that gives me the sensation of a tongue numbing.  Actually that tongue numbing note is really reminding me of the sensation I had last night when accidentally chewing on a clove that was in my bowl of Pho.  This has ample fruit notes to it, with flavors of prunes, raisins, touches of dried figs and concentrated berry flavors all being noticeable.  The body of this beer has a light-medium heft to it; it impacts the palate well with lingering flavors, yet remains quite light feeling.  Strangely enough, I would not classify this beer as quaffable; it seems to have the body for that, but somehow the flavor impact is too large for me to feel comfortable with quaffing this brew (this is most definitely a good thing, given the alcohol percentage of this brew).

This is quite tasty, it has quite a bit more darker grain notes in it than is typical (especially towards the finish), but these notes mostly add another dimension to this brew.  While the aroma is not overly so, the flavor definitely has some heavy spiciness to it (though I wouldnt guess this is anything more than fermentation character).  Fairly rich tasting, yet the overall experience of this beer remains surprisingly light.  Either Dubbels are finally beginning to grow on me (Dubbels have been one of the few Belgian Styles I have not really been exited about), or this is just enough different from the typical example that I am really enjoying this right now.
Drunk 7/5. Caramel/amber color with fluffy tan head. Sweet caramel aroma. The taste was the mainly sweet caramel. Medium body. Better as it warms.

Bottle straight from the brewery. Brown pour, medium white head. Aroma is sour and caramel notes. Flavor has a touch of sourness, caramel, milk chocolate, nutty and toffee. Just a great rich malty flavor that start with a sour touch, caramel and chcolate then ends with a smokey finish.

750. Thanks, GoldTwins! Pours deep murky brown with a thick, creamy off-white head. Plenty of lace--clingy sheets of it. Huge green apple and sour cherry nose. Creamy soft body with very light carb, kind of a thickish mouthfeel. Very subdued flavors throughout the mid-palate and into a very restrained finish. A bit on the polite side, but very clean and drinkable.

Pours red/brown, with a tan head. Aroma is dark fruit, malt, brown sugar,a nd a small amount of bananas. Flavor is dark fruit, yeast, malt, and banana. Creamy body. A solid brew, but a bit steep at $14.

Bottle. Hazy orange/copper color with a large head. Spare lacing, good retention. Aroma was yeast, apple, fig and brown sugar.  Fruity-sweet taste with cherries and lots of yeastiness throughout. Some tartness to finish. Fairly warm for the 8% ABV.

Bottle shared by SpringsLicker with myself, Suttree, and decaturstevo.Pours mahogany with nice beige head. The aroma is charred wood, nuts, very faint banana, and chocolate. The flavor is nut, slight chocolate, and some fruit peels. Just a hint of smoke comes out from time to time. The finish is earthy and meaty. Rather drinkable.

Thanks to Springslicker for sharing this one. Clear brown with a rocky beoge head. Boozy, winey aroma. Nicely sweet and surprisingly crisp. Notes of caramel and grape, with an earthy, or leathery note. Nice and well blended.

Large beige head of medium sized bubbles.  Settles slowly with excellent carbonation.  Malts and vegetal aroma with some spices and dark fruit.  Some ginger in there also along with some toasty bread.  Color is a dark mahagony brown.  Dry crisp flavor.  Spicy and malty.  Almost pasty in the mouth.  Light alcohol presence and warming.  More vegetal flavors in there.  Kind of strange.  Finish is malty and dry and pasty.  A decent dubbel but the mouhtfeel is a little strange.

750 ml bottle.  Pours a mahagony amber color with a medium creamy beige head.  Spicy aroma of banana, nuts, figs and yeast.  Taste is spicy as well with hints of banana, nuts, brown sugar, figs, prunes, plums and fresh yeast.  A slight cotton candy-bubblegum finish.  Very nice and a good slow sipper.

Taste a bctc 2007...
Aroma:Nutty,tobbaco...
Appearance:Light hazy orange,light white head...
Flavor:nutty,tobbaco,light hops flavor...

From a 750mL Bottle.  Mostly transparent, ruddy mahogany colored pour with a medium layer of off-white head.  Slightly tart nose with a crisp fruity acidity of pomegranate seeds and mango flesh.  Light caramel and fig add a bit of darker depth, but the fruity acidity is really the defining aromatic feature.  Light bodied, highly carbonated mouthfeel, but the bubbles have a soft texture.  A bit thin, with a celery-like astringency.  Pinot noir grape skins up front on the palate, rounding out to some mild chocolate mid-palate before finishing with some dry biscuit.  Strange how it starts tart and ends malty.  Thanks for sharing, Chris!

The aroma is very appealing with its dates, soft and sweet caramel malt and spices. It has a cloudy dark amber color with a medium offwhite head. The flavor is sweet but just enough, supple caramel malts mingle with dates, raisins and spices, very pleasant. The body is light to medium with a creamy texture and gentle carbonation. A very well-done and enjoyable dubbel, on the verge of excellence.

Bottle.  Pours dark amber with almost no head.  Candy sugar aroma with a slight hint of alcohol.  Brown sugar, molasses and malt in the flavor.  As it warms the alcohol aspect intensifies.  This is an excellent double.  Definitely one of my favorites especially from such a small local brewery.

Deep hazed orangey brown, fluffy off-white head.  As it warmed, the nose opened up into soft notes of plum, raisin bread, and earthy cinnamon apple.  Had lighter underlying tones of peppery caramel as well.  Nicely balanced flavor with dark fruit notes that sit on a light boozy sweet caramel tone.  Just a touch of hop bitterness late allows for a lightly bittersweet finish.  Medium bodied with soft carbonation.  Thanks to Scott V for sending this bottle my way.  Well done brew that should age with grace...

UPDATED: JUL 10, 2007 Lightly hazy amber with red highlights.  Medium to large slowly dissipating off white head.  Aroma is caramel, light notes of fruit and spice.  Taste is a good deal of caramel with raisins/plums/apple and spices.  Some alcohol warm in the finish.  Seemed almost a bit clean for a dubbel (not much raisin, and yeast mustyness) but it came out more and more as the beer warmed up.  A nice dubbel that will no doubt improve with age.

Very big thanks to puzzl for throwing this bottle in as a bonus.  First thoughts are: pretty darn good dubbel, but I dont love dubbels.  Ive always been impressed with the ability of Belgian yeast to transform malt flavors.  Big presence of plum, grape and raisin.  Just a light touch of that tart grapeskin flavor.  Just malt, malt and more malt with a nice Belgian foundation.  Big rich palate.  Thick and somewhat silky.  Again, a good beer, but just a style that doesnt do much for me.

Hazy, dark amber body with a large rocky, beige head, lasting, nice lace. The aroma is dark fruits, caramel, toffee and light herbal hops. The flavor is slightly sweet, cotton candy, honey, prunes, light spice and herbs. Medium body is very soft and round with moderate carbonation. I would have liked to see a bit less sweetness, but this was still nice.

750:bottled in 06. Supplied by jjpm74, thanks bro!  Poured a medium sized light brown head with good retention and a stringy lace that thinned out shortly. Lightly hazy brown color with a faint ruby hue. Nose if fruity with light bananna notes, hint of raisins, caramel and toffee notes as well. Body is medium, lightly creamy and buttery on the palate. Caramel notes up front, toffeeish with a smattering of raisins,  chocolate and a touch nutty, some bready notes as well. Finish is lightly sweet, faintly smokey and fruity. Would like to try the next batch.Thanks John!

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2007 Re-rate: Bottle courtesy jjpm74. Orangey brown in color, huge tan-orange head, great retention, lacing excellent. The aroma was bubblegum, chocolate, plumey. Flavor was much the same, some licorice, coriander notes, grapes, yeasty-spicey bitter finish. Mouthfeel was airy-creamy. A nice job on the style, although the style has slipped a little in my overall likes. Original rating: Bottle courtesy slob. Orangey light brown color, decent head, thinning quickly but steady. The lacing was ok. The aroma was light notes of smoke, roast, caramel, chocolate, harsh vinous notes (the latter almost a turn-off). The flavor picked up the pace, especially as this thing warmed: Nut caramel, chocoalte, light roast, yeast, light fruits (pears, grapes?). Mouthfeel not as full and airy/fluffy like a classic dubbel, yet with warmer temperatures, not too bad. Thanks, Bert.

i was kinda disappointed by this. honestly, for a dubbel it was severely lacking in aroma or flavor. it looked really nice....full head with nice lacing. however, the typical dubbel aromas and flavors (dark fruits, touch of yeast, etc) were there but highly muted. this bottle was about a year old but maybe it needed more time to truly develop the flavors.

This offering from Captain Lawrence pours an unfiltered dark brown beauty. The nose is dark ripened pitted fruit (Plums, Raisins, Prunes) with a brown sugar sweetness followed by just a slight hoppy bitterness of tart unripened fruit as suppose to citrus to help balance the malty sweetness. The finish is a bit rough, at 8% it is not too hot and the overall mouthfeel is young and a bit raw for a dubbel. I think age would do this Dubbel some good but it is still a nice sipper.

UPDATED: APR 27, 2007 2006 bottling: Rusty orange. Bottle conditioning yields a broken layer of clingy dirty-white foam. Red licorice, rum-soaked raisins and plasticy phenols comprise the aroma, with sweet hints of chocolate cake and caramelized malt underneath. Very brightly fruity. Airy on the palate with expressive, yet snug, carbonation. Resoundingly malty, initially, and succulently fruity, with a caramel-drizzled fudge cake richness which is gently displaced by a vivaciously phenolic accompaniment. Medicinal alcohol generates substantial chest warmth, but doesnt overly detract. Clean attenuation, coupled with trace unripe plum acidity, helps to add lift and refreshment. Malt is deceptively pronounced, but flashes of  graininess do exude. Extremely clean, though a glimpse of waxy yeast appears which accentuates the sugared-cranberry sweetness. Finishes slightly medicinally astringent, but dryish and mostly nuanced with hints of rummy raisins, candy apples, plum skin, and deeply caramelized malt. A delightfully clean and well-attenuated rendition.  Maybe a bit alcoholic, but the malt is complex yet occasionally subtle, and the sweetness and yeastiness are thankfully reserved. Thanks to puzzl for the bottle.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Slightly hazy reddish-brown beer with a pastel yellow, fine and thick head. Piney, resiny hops and milk chocolate nose. Spruce or fir tree wood & needles. In the background some bitter chocolate as well, and dark (decidous) leaves. Very Walloon in character: chocolate, just a bit of mild coffee, very leafy, earthy, and still some fir tree, but less resinous than the nose. Maybe a tad more hoppy than its Walloon forebears, as well as bitter almonds extra. Quite bitter aftertaste, becoming dry. Medium to well bodied. Well attenuated, maybe a bit more than a usual Belgian dubbel. Very good Belgian dark strong ale. I wouldnt call it a double - then I only would call Westmalle and La Trappe as such.  White Labs or Wyeast N°...? Many thanks to Brian.

Bottle sampled on 8/26/06: Pours a clear, mostly still copper amber with a thin, wispy white head.  Aroma of slightly toasty bready dark caramel malt with a touch of Belgian yeast.  Thinner, lightly sweet body is not that complex for the style, but is very drinkable.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2007 Batch 1.  750 ml bottle.  Very clear light brown beer with a thick pillowy head.  Aroma is excellent with a sweet and vineous character.  Oaky and fruity with cherry, red grapes, bubble gum, clove and a bit of sweet rummy brown sugar character.  Very fruity and practically oozes ripe berries (blackberry, cherry, strawberry).  Some sweet bready malts that are both toasty and add a chewy palate to the brew.  Flavour matches the aroma with sweet blackberry/blueberry character behind a spicy yeast character.  Clove and allspice mixed with juicy fruit gum and a heavy wheaty spiciness.  Full sweet palate, with raisins and plummy malts all contributing to the brews flavour.  As the temperature comes up, a great fresh minty hop aroma/flavour comes up helping to soften all the sweet fruits and spices.  This is a very fruity, but well-balanced and very tasty brew.  One of the best Ive had from this up and coming brewery.  I cant wait to try what else they have coming down the line.


750 ml bottle batch 2.  Deep orange-tinted brown with a thick light tan head.  Sweet plummy aroma, rye toast, wheaty spice and a lots of cherry and dried fruits.  Orange peel, clove and lighter berryish notes.  Flavour is sweet but shows lots of malty complexity.  A soft earthy component as well.  Some Belgian caramel, toffee, and sweet cherry/berry, plum fruitiness.  Spicy finish with a touch more bitterness than I might normally expect in this style.  Great balance of sweet malts and spicy yeastiness.  Very bready on the back with a light hit of black pepper.
